At the window in the blue-threaded light of three in the morning, Mara pressed her palm flat to the pane. The ring was warm. The river moved as if someone had put a chord under it. She did not promise herself away. She did not promise herself to herself, either; the world had taught her that was a dangerous sort of vow. She breathed and counted to seven and then lost the numbers because a rhythm had found her that was not counting and was not silence and was not the city taking what it wanted. It was the small sound you make when you decide to be brave again tomorrow. It was not an anthem. It did not have a beat you could dance to, unless your dance was the sort where you lean on a counter and laugh too loud so you will know you are alive.Morning took a long time deciding to arrive in the Old Weavers and, when it did, it came through the kitchen window like someone late to a party bringing bread to apologize. Edda had already done the practical warfare of wiping down the table twice, not because it was dirty but because doing so put the world temporarily into her jurisdiction. The paper flower sat under a mixing bowl, which made the cat very religious about the bowl, circling it and saying quiet cat things to it as if prayer would keep unfortunate paper from learning new tricks. Mara poured tea and did not put the ring on until she had watched the steam for three long breaths and decided she had the edges for it. The weight on her finger altered the taste of the tea; she could taste a faint metal that was not cup and not spoon, an optimism that made her want to swear and knock on wood simultaneously.

Kestrel arrived with a speed that made you suspect she had been downstairs on the second-floor landing timing the moments between footsteps. She threw herself into a chair like it was about to be stolen and put a folded piece of onion-skin paper on the table with reverence and profanity co-existing in the gesture. The paper was thinner than a whisper and twice as sure of itself. Inside it, a hand had written with a nib that had a lot of opinions: We have hot water and we do not waste it on men. Bring your throat. Old Baths, noon. It smelled faintly of rosemary, the way old sweat can if it has been mixed with years of soap and women’s conversations about things no council ever included on their agendas.

Edda dried her hands and looked at the paper like it came from a school friend she had laughed with three governments ago. She touched the edge and then touched Mara’s wrist. “You should go,” she said, and the should had a weight to it like a bowl you set down firmly so that it doesn’t try to participate in the argument. “If you are going to carry a ring with this much bad manners, you should at least speak with the women who taught the last one to mind its shoes indoors.”

Mara wanted to say she had a meeting with Pax and another meeting with a man whose job title was a form of apology, but the paper’s rosemary smell reached into her and arranged her objections into less useful shapes. She drank the tea. She ate the end of a heel of bread she did not want. She put her hand flat over the bowl with the paper flower and felt nothing but porcelain and inherited stubbornness, which relieved her more than she expected it to. “Noon,” she said, and saw the way both women in the room half exhaled like a bellows releasing.

The Old Baths had been retired three times—by war, by fashion, by men who liked to put taxes on things women enjoyed—and survived each retirement by pretending to be a ruin until the new rules forgot they existed. The street outside them did not remember when carriages had clattered and men had tipped hats; it remembered quilts hung on lines and steam like early fog and small, savage arguments over which soap made the best lather for hair that behaved like weather. The door had a polite sign that said Closed for Private Restoration, which was the city’s way of saying You do not have enough knowledge to come in right now. Kestrel knocked the knock women knock in funny corners to tell other women they are not here to rearrange anybody. The lock took a moment to remember who it had been forged for and then yielded with a sound like a small regret.

Inside, the air was gratitude and humidity. The tiled room had not been allowed to be pretty; it had insisted on it instead. On the far wall, under a fresco of women with hair like rivers who had lasted out three faiths and never been repainted, sat six women and a kettle. They were not old or young. They were all the ages that mattered. Three of them were now-famous cowards who had refused to stand up and sing when asked by a dead church with a live appetite and the city had survived anyway. Two wore smocks. One wore a coat with pockets that were either full of instruments or full of small knives. None of them stood. None of them smiled in the preliminary way.

“You,” said the one in the coat, who had salt on her cuffs and steam in her voice. “You argued with the water last night until it remembered it needed to boil. Sit. Shoes off. Rings off. We do not drop things in the hot that we haven’t named.”

Mara took off her boots and set them aside with the care you use for friends. She slipped the ring and put it on her palm. It hummed exactly once like a short laugh, and then made a display of being obedient. She sat on the tile, which cooled her at once and made her feel like a child at kitchen level. Kestrel sat cross-legged beside her, and the eyeliner made her look like a very precise heretic. The kettle poured into small cups as if pouring were a sacrament and not a mechanics of gravity.

“We are not the Choir,” said a woman with a line of scars that disappeared under the neck of her shirt and reappeared near her wrist like a small river that got lost and then found itself again. “We were the whisper behind the Choir, the aunties, the thieves, the ones who wrote the lists when the men thought lists were theirs. The Choir scattered rather than be told when to inhale. We did not scatter. We went to make soap and raise boys and teach girls that singing is not performance, it is barricade. The card you got was rude. We do apologies after. I am Soria.”

Mara balanced the cup in both hands and dared to smell it. It was not rosemary. It was lavender and something like iron. It was the smell of the basin in her grandmother’s yard, the one she remembered without ever having seen. “I am Mara,” she said, and felt foolish at introducing herself to women who had already decided what she was to them. “I have something that doesn’t belong to me and I used it and it worked and now the city is making noises like furniture being dragged upstairs at an hour when furniture should not be dragged anywhere. I don’t want to be owned by it. Or by the city. Or by anyone with a patch. I also don’t want to let the Gates go back to sleep. How ridiculous to want anything at all.”

Kestrel put a shoulder lightly against Mara’s as if to stop her from listing too hard. Soria made a how-old-are-you face that had nothing to do with numbers and everything to do with what you had given up to keep your throat for yourself. “It does not belong to anyone,” she said. “The ring belongs to the city we want, not to the city we have. It is not obedient. It prefers cleverness. You have some. You will need more. They will ask you to give it back to sleep. They will say that sleep is safer. Perhaps for them. You will go on not sleeping well for a while. The only thing you must not do is pretend to be quiet when you are not built for it. That will ruin you. We prefer our girls unruined, or at least ruined in interesting ways that annoy the correct men.”

A laugh went around the tile like quick water. Mara tried out the smile that was showing up on the faces of women who were not her and found that it fit her mouth as if it had been there before. “The song last night,” said the one with the pockets of tools or knives, and her voice had a tiny line in it that said she had once been paid to sing to men who could not find sleep any other way. “There was a bleed. Did you feel it.”

Mara thought of sugar underground and men in tunnels tasting sweets that had no business in rust. “Something else rode it,” she said, and the women made the sound women make when they have been waiting to hear someone else say the thing their bodies had already told them. “I was told to keep it dirty and I did and something took the dirt and drew in it. It made an O. It pressed itself against a door and did not knock.”

“The ash faction isn’t interested in asking,” said Soria, which made the tile feel briefly colder. “That is someone else. We thought perhaps one of the Quiets had gotten out of a grave and decided to be polite before being unkind. But the politeness smelled like sugar, which they thought was a sin and which we know to be breakfast. There is a girl under the river who uses sugar to teach ash to be letters. She is either going to save us or make a very beautiful mess. Both, probably.”

Kestrel made a face that announced her two opinions about girls under rivers and both of those opinions involved rescuing and lecturing. Mara looked down at the ring and thought about letters that were almost doors and men laughing where they should not be allowed to. “I heard a laugh,” she said, and watched the flinch happen not on Soria’s face but in the shoulders of the woman three over, who had put her cup down without quite knowing she was going to. “It was not near me. It was near a seam someone I don’t know was not touching. I dislike laughter without a body. It makes my skin feel like it’s being written on.”

“You will have to learn seams,” said Soria. “They are where the city keeps its forgettings. They are often next to places where men are stored. You will leave those alone unless you intend to open them and what comes out is your responsibility forever. We will teach you the vowel that tells seams they are unattractive to you. It is a vowel men cannot make well because it requires a flexibility they do not cultivate.”

They did not sing in the way Mara had expected women in an old bath to sing. They breathed on a note together and the room shifted the way a large animal adjusts under your hand so your palm rests in the right place for its bones. They showed her how to shape her mouth to make the safer-latch tune she had invented last night sit on her tongue and ready itself to be given away without robbing her more than she could spare. They put her feet in hot water and told her to count until she forgot numbers and remembered rhythm. They told her to think of onion soup and then of knives. They told her to invent for herself an ugly cheer so that when she had to sing beautiful she would still have an unbeautiful thing she could hold that was just for her.

When they were done teaching her the vowel and three bad-tempered consonants that belonged with it, Soria took the ring on her palm and let the water fog roll over it. The ring fogged and then cleared itself without anyone making a move. The women nodded because sometimes your tools are alive and it is good to see them wipe their own mouth after eating. “They will want to audit you,” Soria said, passing the ring back. “They will want to list your body and the parts of it they think belong to documents. If you sign, make sure the paper becomes yours. Name it. Bite it a little if you have to.”

Outside, noon made light like a man whittling a piece of wood and getting too much pleasure out of the neatness of the curls. Pax was in the car because of course he was; he had a way of being where you had decided you would need him five minutes before you knew you would. He wore a tie now as a personal experiment in not cursing at men older than him when he had to say sentences with words like proper channels in them. He opened the door and his face made the expression a person makes when they see a room has rinsed you and given you back your skin. It was both admiration and end-of-the-world relief. Kestrel did a little bow so low it upset two pigeons and slid in after Mara like she had paid to be there and refused a refund.

“They want to log the ring as an object of city interest,” Pax said without saying hello, because hello felt like a word you used when nothing was on fire. “Annotations sent a form that is almost reasonable, which makes me suspicious. The Division wants a copy. The Lord Governor wants a statement we write for him that makes him sound less like a man who was delivered to this job as a prank. Roe wants to know if you swallowed a bee on that fifth phrase because she can weave it out if it starts to sting the wrong place. Also the pastry woman sent me a note that says she will accept my promise and my favor and would I like jam.”

Mara held the ring in her fist because it made her feel less like a thing with a handle. “I went to the Baths,” she said, and Pax’s eyes did the small close-lid thing like a man closing the door to his better nature before he said something careless. “They taught me a vowel. They told me not to open seams even if someone with a laugh asks me to. They used sugar to talk about ash. There is a girl under the river doing geometry with candy and we should either help her or steal her, and I find that I am too tired to know which is moral.”

Pax turned his head just enough that she could see the part of his face that would never be televised, the part that got young when he was letting himself be more dangerous than useful. “Good,” he said softly. “If they like you they will save your life two or three times in ways that aren’t dramatic enough to be fun. If they don’t like you they will merely keep you from embarrassing yourself in public, which is kindness of another order. We have to go to Annotations. We will smile and use the word consent until a man tries to bite his tongue off.”

Annotations lived in a building that had been a bank and had not learned to be different. The foyer had floors that made your heel sound seditious. The elevator smelled oily and safe. The reception desk was a beautiful woman with a mouth like a ledger. Aron Tull met them with a card already in his hand, which meant he had practiced the smile he wanted to wear when the person he intended to put in a folder arrived not wanting to be a folder. He wore gray the way some men wear wars, like a garment they were never meant to take off.

“The form is a form,” he said, and even his hands looked like paper. “It says the object is declared, the chain of provenance is under inquiry, and the bearer is recognized as temporarily authorized for civic broadcast activities under supervision. It protects you. It protects us from you. It protects the city from both of us.”

Pax sat with the elegant violence of a man who knows the power of chairs and is prepared to wield it. “It is ten words too long,” he said, and smiled with nine teeth and not the tenth. “It says supervision. The Charter says counsel. It is a famous difference. It says chain of provenance, which would be a lovely phrase to write poetry about if you were a poet and it did not mean men with stamps get to tell stories about women’s throats. You may have a form. It may not have that language.”

Aron’s expression did a small calculation that would have been attractive if it were not being performed on a person he wanted to inventory. “We can change a word,” he conceded as if he were lowering a drawbridge in a house with no moat. “We would also like an impression of the ring. For the registry.”

Mara put her hands on the table and her ring hand not on the paper. She could feel Kestrel next to her making a silent scream face because Kestrel had never met a registry she liked. She looked at the page and thought of Soria’s advice. She thought of biting. She thought of naming paper until it belonged to her instead of to the man who had printed it. She picked up the pen and wrote her name and then, without asking, wrote: I name this paper and its brothers a comfort. You may not be used to being named. Learn.

Aron read the sentence and smiled in the way men smile when they have been outflanked in a petty way and intend to win later when no one is watching. “We respect language,” he said, and put a stamp on the bottom that made the sheet buzz very gently like it had swallowed a fly. “We will get out of your hair. Do remember to return our calls. If the Sovereign’s ash starts to shake itself onto our chairs and leave shape-words, we will wish we had more forms, not fewer.”

They left with a copy of the paper that had learned its new name and with a memory of Aron’s smile that would be useful later in identifying which weapon he thought he was holding. Pax put his hand on the low of Mara’s back as they walked out, his fingers an inch away from contact as if he were restraining himself from being the sort of man who guided women with his palm. “They are going to try very nicely,” he said in the tone men used to talk about storms when the windows were already rattling. “The Division will not be nice. I have a friend on the lower stairs who thinks he can keep the word custodian off your file. That friend will either become our problem soon or our prayer. Meanwhile, Roe is in a mood. She found something in the recording she has not seen since—well. Since I had a different hairstyle and did not believe in my own death.”

Hollow Sun was a different building by daylight. It had been designed to make you love it at night, which meant that in the morning it looked like the aftermath of a party you were too clever to attend. Roe was in her chair, which was not a throne because she would have burned a throne for warmth. She had four screens up: one with waveforms, one with a map of the old Quietite runes lit to show passage, one with a cartoon cat, and one with a list of equipment requests she had previously been told were extravagant and would now be met because the city had remembered to be frightened.

“You invited a passenger,” she said without saying hello, and pointed with her chin at the waveform where, under Mara’s vocal, there ran the faintest of other voices like a silk thread under a coarse seam. “You left the line open and something leaned in and said its name without saying it. This is not ash. This is—this is something that knows the old way a door opens and has been respectful about knocking because it wants to be invited to dinner rather than let itself in and eat the cat.”

Pax took his jacket off as if he had been dying to do so since breakfast. “Sugar,” he said, because he liked to get there first sometimes even when it didn’t matter. “Caelan smelled sugar underground. Soria says there’s a girl with lessons in candy. You’re telling us the ring chased itself down a sweet and found a seam.”

“I am telling you not to open it,” Roe said, and looked at Mara with the unsmiling courtesy of someone who had stood beside enough disasters to have a palate for their taste. “You are tired and tired people make bargains with doors because doors look like answers when your feet hurt. The seam has a frequency. I will write you the note that tells it to mind its business for a day and a night. After that, if it is still polite, we ask it if its mother taught it to rinse cups or put them in the sink dirty. That will tell us which side raised it.”

The day tried very hard, then, to behave like a day. They did three interviews. Mara answered questions while wearing sunglasses that did not make her invisible and did make her feel like a friend of theirs would appear if she reached for her pocket. Pax lied successfully on her behalf twice and was honest once on accident. Roe delivered the note handwritten on the back of a bus schedule: a set of bars with no clef and the barest notations in the corner in an alphabet that did not announce itself to strangers. Kestrel stole three pastries and shared two. Edda called twice to ask if anyone would be home to eat the stew that had suddenly decided it needed to exist.

By late afternoon, the part of a city’s day when everyone’s temper gets thin and their posture worse, Caelan sent a message that was not a message, because he did not believe in making himself easy to subpoena. It was a bouquet of words delivered by a boy who smelled of coal dust and soup: bridge, south, sugar again, be clever, no heroics. Pax read it and did a thing with his mouth that meant he would be heroic in a way no one could blame him for later. Mara read it and felt an irritation that was almost relief. Kestrel read it and said absolutely not out loud and then yes under her breath because the under-breath is where your bravery negotiates with your sense.

The bridge at South Span had several moods, and that afternoon it wore the one that said it had put up with hurricanes and weddings and men who thought a proposal needed an audience; it would put up with this as well. Lancers in plain clothes had made the crowd look like a crowd that did not intend to panic. Caelan was where he belonged in a space like that: nowhere obvious and everywhere at once, the way a sound can come from a wall you didn’t realize had a body behind it. The ash traces were not dramatic. They were less than the dust from a baker’s sleeve and more than should be, arranged in a shape that had gotten to the second letter and been interrupted by a hand that decided to behave. There was sugar too, which glittered when the light hit it and sank into the ash with the tenderness of ingredients in a batter.

“We are going to keep people moving,” Caelan said into the small boil of attention Pax carried with him into any scene. “We are not going to say the words you must not say. We are going to stand here like the city watching the river and we are not going to be impressed. We are not going to be provoked. If the seam shows its teeth, you are going to sing that note Roe gave you quietly enough that only doors hear it. If the ash tries to be beautiful, you will not praise it.”

Mara nodded because nodding was safer than promising. The ring warmed without asking her permission to do so. She took a position not in the middle and not on the edge and watched the light change along the surface of the river with the kind of attention that makes you forget where your hands are. The crowd, being a crowd, did crowd things: moved forward, moved back, made a sound that was half complaint and half thrill. Kestrel started a conversation with a woman whose job was cutting keys and who had strong opinions about the way men understood locks and none of those opinions were positive. Pax, as was his religious habit, refused to stand still and therefore could be in four very necessary places in five minutes.

The seam made the smallest surrender of itself and then stopped. The ash became an O again the way a mouth does when it has decided to say one thing and thinks better of it. The sugar glinted as if some ridiculous child under the river had whispered Now. Mara put the note in her mouth and hummed it inward like a coin you swallow because someone is trying to take it from you. The seam did not open. It acknowledged and retreated. Caelan relaxed a degree no one else on the bridge was trained to detect.

It would have ended as well as anything ends in a city like Eydolon—untidily and almost—if three men had not decided they were very tired of quiet. They were not ash. They were not sugar. They were the sort of men who sell other men maps to places that never existed and then get offended when those men show up at their doors and ask for a refund. They had knives they were proud of and jackets that made them look like they had joined a club which would let in any man who liked jackets. One of them had a paper flower pinned to his lapel with a safety pin, and the paper did not turn to ash because whoever had made it had calculated the weather.

They moved toward the place where the seam had let its O be visible and Caelan was there before their forward momentum could get them into any useful trouble. He did not draw a weapon. He did not need to. The particular way he put his foot down was architectural; the air around a step like that gets busy making a wall because it suspects it might be safer to be masonry right now. The man with the paper flower smiled a smile he had practiced in front of a mirror with the sound of other people’s fear as his accompaniment. “We just want a look,” he said, inserting his voice into the public space the way you insert a knife into a letter you are not meant to read. “Want to see what the city thinks it’s hiding.”

“What the city keeps to itself,” Caelan said, and his tone did not rise, “is the reason you can stand here this afternoon and pretend to be a part of it.”

The man looked past him with the audacity of fools. He saw Mara and did a small calculation almost as quickly as Aron Tull had and came up with different numbers. He did not look at her hands because some men are very good at not looking where you ought to look and very bad at looking where you must not. “Singer,” he said, with the tone that makes the word an accusation and a proposition at once. “You brought a song down here. Sing again. Let it through.”

Mara had spent a long time in rooms where men told her to smile and did not believe her when she said, No. The old baths had put a vowel in her mouth that told the city to look elsewhere. Roe’s bus-schedule had drawn her a line to keep her feet on. She touched the ring with the thumb of her other hand because a part of her was still a fool for ritual. Then she said, very pleasantly, as if she were at the pastry counter and the last beautiful thing had just been bought by someone else, “No.”

The man smiled because he thought he was owed another word. He reached for her because men who think they are owed say more with their arms than with their mouths. He did not reach her. Caelan moved without the flourish he could allow himself when he fought men with practice. He put two fingers against the man’s wrist and reminded the man of the anatomy he had forgotten, that there is a bone under the skin that will tell you stories you cannot pretend are not true. The knife dropped, which was undramatic but helpful. Jaro relieved a second man of the pretense he had ever been allowed to be dangerous in public, and Ran spoke softly into the ear of the third until his body remembered that breathing is a condition and not a promise.

There was a moment when it could have become a thing people wrote speeches about. The seam did its small not-enough trick. The ash lifted and made the barest flourish of a new shape. The sugar drifted like snow. Kestrel grabbed Mara’s elbow and pretended she was the one holding her up when what she was doing was making herself a wall you had to go through if you wanted to put your hands on her friend. Pax moved a half step forward and then stopped because he was learning, which looked like hesitation but was the bravest thing he could teach himself.

Mara hummed the note again. She put her mouth near the seam without touching it and said the vowel Soria had pressed into her like a seed pressed into dirt. The seam made a disappointed sound very few people heard because it was a sound you know only if you have ever been a door with excellent intentions. The ash fell. The men were collected by the city the way a spill is collected by good rags. The bridge, having seen better and worse, pretended it had been an afternoon like any other.

They did not celebrate. They went home the way you go home after you have refused to let the wrong thing happen in public: with the particular quiet of people who do not want to give the day the satisfaction of not having ruined them. Pax made stew consumption an official requirement. Kestrel made Edda laugh with three new words she had invented on the way over. Caelan stood at the parapet and looked at the place where the ash had tried to spell a second letter and let his face admit to the sort of fear that wakes you and makes you check, at four in the morning, that the doors are all still on the hinges.

Marrowgate breathed in the way big buildings breathe when dusk pushes the heat back into the core. Silas had written a paragraph he did not hate, which made him distrust the paragraph immediately. Lale returned his papers with a note on the top in a handwriting that looked like a good staircase: If you write three more, I can pay you in something other than apples. I am thinking of stamps. Try to keep your sentences from killing anyone. It will make my job with the censors shorter. He read it twice and then put it under the thin pillow because people steal fewer jokes than food, and he would rather be hungry than humorless.

He felt the seam when the city let out that small disappointed door-sound. He did not know what the sound was and his body learned it anyway. He looked at the wall as if it had learned his name and then politely forgotten it because it had company. He stood without deciding to stand and put his hand to the place the seam had taught him to find with the blind second sight people grow in cages. Across the city a woman pressed a vowel into stone and a vampire told a door to behave. The vibration through his bones ended at a frequency that made the skin at the back of his neck try to climb into his hair. He laughed, not nicely, and immediately apologized to the room without using any words because he had long since learned walls hold grudges.

Night behaved for a few hours. Men in coats stopped working at their desks and looked at their children as if they were borrowed and due back. The pastry shop shooed the last people out with the sort of bedtime stories only sugar can make. Roe fell asleep in her chair with her hand on the mouse and the mouse had the decency not to go waking things up while she wasn’t watching. Soria locked the Baths and then unlocked them because she remembered a girl used the back entrance when she needed to sit in the heat alone and talk herself out of making a glorious mistake. Edda put the bowl back over the paper flower because the devil does not get tired even when you do.

Then the city did what it always does when you believe you have negotiated one more day from it. It asked a price in a different currency. At three a great many windows hummed. Not screaming, not singing, not shattering. Humming, like a throat warming up. Mara sat up in the bed without the part where she wakes and sat and in the sitting was a wakefulness that had nothing to do with sleep or the absence of it. The ring warmed and then cooled as if it had put on a coat and taken it off again in the wrong season. Outside, low and along the river, a small procession of light moved like a thought a man doesn’t want to finish.

Caelan was on the parapet; that was his foolishness and his virtue. He saw the procession and did not call for trumpets. He did not like trumpets for first drafts. He sent the small signal that meant bring me twelve and the kind who know that knees matter as much as shoulders. The procession was too orderly to be ash and too cautious to be Lancers and too quiet to be the city being itself on a night it could get away with it. It looked like men carrying something that had been heavy once and had remembered to be light.

They brought the thing into the switchyard and put it down with the care you give equipment that saved you once and could break you now if you looked like you didn’t respect it. It was a door in a frame with no wall, and the door was made of glass that had been broken and mended with metal that had learned humility late and was very good at pretending. The men stepped back. They were not ash. They were not officers. They were city workers with good shoulders and the kind of look you acquire when a supervisor tells you to do a thing and you do it but you also decide privately whether that thing belongs to this city or some other you do not consent to.

Caelan put his hand out the way you put your hand out to an animal that has already decided whether it will bite you. The door did not move. Behind him, Jaro said a word that would have made Soria throw a bar of soap at his head. Ran sucked her teeth and then asked, because she was the one with a questions inventory, “Where did you find a Quietite door you could carry.”

The man in front with the practical shoulders scratched his nose, which made him human, and said, “We didn’t. It was leaned up under the bridge. Like somebody had needed to take it out for air.”

The door hummed. The same hum the windows had. The same hum the seam had admitted but not consented to. Caelan did not call Pax because this had gone past art and into religion and he disliked to be observed while taking sacraments. He did not call Mara because three in the morning belonged to her for sleeping even if the city wanted to make it otherwise. He did not call the Division because once you invite them to your party you will find your guest list has been altered for the rest of your social life. He put his hand on the glass with the insolent humility that had kept him alive longer than many. The glass was not cold and not warm. It tasted in his bones like sugar and ash have a child together and no one wants to talk about whose eyes it got.

He said, because it had worked once, “Not tonight.”

The door hummed exactly once and then shut itself, which was a neat trick given it was already closed. The hum ran off into the rails and along the river and into small kitchens where kettles tried to remember if they were alive. Mara lay back down and counted until numbers were not numbers again. Silas sat on the floor with his back to the seam and sang under his breath very badly on purpose because it was a song that did not belong to him and he thought perhaps if he were rude to it, it would go away like a wrong cat.

By dawn the door was gone. Someone had moved it or it had decided to move itself and the Lancers looked at the empty space and did the particular shoulder motion that meant a thing had happened and they would deal with the next thing instead. Roe woke with a stiff neck and a flood of messages and one note under her mouse, which made her feel homicidal and fond at once. The note said: sugar is not the enemy. It had no signature, and three grains of sugar glued themselves to her thumb as if to prove a point.

At breakfast, Edda lifted the bowl and the paper flower was still paper. She took it in both hands, went to the sink, and held it over the drain. She looked at her daughter, and her daughter nodded as if in a ritual someone would write down later. Edda tore the paper gently into small pieces and then smaller. She turned on the tap and held the pieces in the water until they were pulp. She did not wash them away. She took the pulp and pressed it flat and set it by the window to dry as a new sheet. “You do not get to say what you are,” she told it. “I do.”

Mara ate bread and stew and sugar off her thumb and watched the world be very brave in small ways. She had a meeting at ten with a woman whose job was to make men in another building believe there was a budget for art and a ferocity at noon with Pax about where the money would come from if there was not. She had a promise with Caelan for later about south tunnels and the kind of map you do not draw on paper. She had to send Roe a recording of a humming because the engineer wanted to build a fence out of it. She had to write to Kestrel a message that said I will not be brave if brave means being stupid. She had to breathe.

Outside, the billboards had finally changed. They did not have the right face up yet—the city is always late to its own party—but they had stopped pretending nothing had happened. The Gate towers did their quiet advertisement. The pigeons tilted their heads like old men remembering a joke. The river carried on. Somewhere under it, a girl with sticky fingers counted sugar grains like notes. Somewhere in a building with a seam, a man wrote three more paragraphs and did not write the boy’s name because he had written it enough for one life. Somewhere on a parapet, a vampire lord looked at a place where a door had been and rolled his shoulders and felt ancient and, against his will, interested.

And somewhere in a bath where the mural’s women had new water on their hair, Soria wrote a line on the wall with steam that said, in a hand the city used to pick locks, If you are going to ruin yourself, do it to a rhythm that makes a decent story. Then the water ran and the steam blurred it and the line went into the tile, which is where the city keeps the advice it refuses to frame.Chapter 8

The budget woman had a smile like a stapler and a wall of framed certificates that tried to convince you she had been born at a desk and had never known the indignity of a kitchen towel. She wore her hair in the kind of bun mothers save for funerals and for days when their daughters say they want to learn to ride other people’s motorcycles. Her office window faced a brick wall because no one trusted cultural funding to survive a view. She introduced herself as Deputy Comptroller Riane Pell in a tone that made each syllable an invoice and asked Mara to sit without looking at the chair, as if chairs had chosen her long ago and she no longer had to negotiate with them.

Pax did not sit because he believed in the psychology of legs and because he liked to make paper-heavy rooms remember a body. He spoke first, not to antagonize but to put a layer of plausible charm over the fact that his mere arrival made her budget sheets itch. He laid out the arithmetic the way a man tells you a story with the fair parts in it. Charter Song broadcast. Training morale. The small measurable reductions in injury during patrols when men marched with something to hum under their teeth instead of the tired version of themselves. The tiny uptick in bread sales in the northern quarter at dawn which meant bakers were confident enough to bake extra and people had decided to mix yeast with hope, not scarcity.

Deputy Pell listened with her eyes on a point beyond Pax’s shoulder, which was where she kept a picture of her grandmother in a hat you only wore when there were parades. She let him free-climb the side of her building without a rope and then gave him nothing but a handkerchief. Grants were closed for the quarter. Emergency disbursement required an Event Code number. In-kind support could be offered if they registered the ring as an asset under City Holdings. The phrase in-kind tasted like paper dipped in broth and called a meal. She said it with a clean mouth anyway.

Mara had expected to be bored and then to be angry in a small, elegant way that carried no calories. She found herself instead watching the woman’s hands. They were older than the hair and younger than the mouth and they hold a pen like a wand someone had told her was a sword before she learned what swords are for. She thought of all the ways women learned to negotiate with men who came asking for money to make noise and how sometimes the cheapest thing you could spend was affection. She did not spend it. She explained instead that if the city decided to hold the ring in a room with inventory numbers on pegs, then the city could keep the keys and she would go back to singing in kitchens with the taps yelling, and the Night Lancers could march to the sound of their own boots, which was a fine beat for a funeral.

Deputy Pell’s stapler-smile flickered, which was not victory but a movement some women make when another woman says No in public and the room does not fall down. She asked how much, then, if money could be convinced to wear a dress and meet them in a hallway for five minutes. Roe had given Pax numbers written in two inks, one that said truth and one that said lie for the Lord Governor. Pax gave the truth and cut off the last digit because he intended to get it back in favors and hardware. Deputy Pell wrote a figure down and Mara watched the ink turn into a kind of altar. The woman had a budget for clean water and broken windows and paying the six men who wrote speeches and the two women who made those speeches into sentences someone could keep in their mouths. Somewhere she had found a pocket where you keep money for the kind of days that shake your hand and the bone under your hand at once. She opened it enough to be insulting if you were greedy or a blessing if you had their sense of humor.

When they left, Pax kissed the air near the Deputy’s temple as if to say we have both survived worse and I will not tell if you do not. On the steps in the sun, he leaned against a column like a man who had fallen in love with architecture and knew better. He told Mara that he had once thought money could be sung into existence and learned it could only be conned, cajoled, borrowed, and wedged under doors until the door couldn’t close on you without admitting its bad manners. He asked her if she could bear to sing again by nightfall if someone else’s bad manners insisted we must. She said she would eat stew first and then perhaps set a small fire in the bath to keep her courage hot. He promised stew, bath, courage, fire, and then gave her the kind of smile he hid from crowds because it made them forgiving and forgiveness was a commodity the city refused to trade honestly.

The south tunnels were a temperature you usually only found inside rivers and behind old church doors. Caelan met them where the rail dipped and was forced to confess it had never been properly level. He wore his crest without polish and had a smear of something on his sleeve that could have been oil or old blood and which he had not had time to decide on in a way he approved. Ran went ahead like a thought you had on purpose; Jaro brought up the rear like the line at a bakery after rain. Mara felt the ring like a dog that refuses to heel and also refuses to run away. She hummed Roe’s seam-note under her breath because sometimes warding is rehearsing not to scream.

The sugar was not a dust now. It was a logic. Somebody had arranged bright grains along the line of old runes that hadn’t been pressed by a foot in a generation. The pattern didn’t match the book the Division printed and issued to warders in a package with a brass whistle and an oath you were meant to revise as needed. It matched something else, something the room liked and had been embarrassed about remembering. The ash had set in little hairline patches where the sugar stuck rather than melted, as if it had decided it wanted to touch sweetness and did not know how to behave on a first meeting.

A girl sat twelve yards ahead on a crate that had once held apples and now held a chemistry of items the city would not list under ingredients. She had a sack of sugar tied at three points so that any thief who cut it would split it into three petty disappointments. She had a tin of salt, a glass jar of borrowed honey sealed with wax like a promise someone made in a kitchen with witnesses, and a box of hard candy stolen from a hospital cart or gifted by a nurse with a look that said keep your mouth shut when you enjoy this. Her hair was tied with a ribbon that had been string in its past life and would be a handle in its next. She looked at Mara and Caelan the way gulls look at storms and did not move. It took Mara a too-long second to realize why the girl’s face carried the kind of stillness people try to cultivate in meditation and achieve once at most, usually in a disaster. The stillness was not composure. It was the habit of someone who had not been spoken to often enough to get good at performing speech for other people’s comfort.

Kestrel, who had insisted on coming because she had made an appointment with her own regret to meet at the end of the day and did not intend to be late, stopped just behind Mara and took the exact measure of the sugar in one glance because women like her grew up measuring grams with their eyes and deciding if you could get away with stealing one. She swallowed something that might have been the impulse to be the first to speak.

Caelan did it for all of them and took his gloves off first because he was not stupid enough to reach for a child with his hands dressed for war. He tilted his head and let his mouth be less severe. He asked, in a voice a dog would bring a shoe to, “Is this your work.”

The girl looked at the ash like it had offered her a ride and she had declined. She did not nod and did not shake her head, because koans are fine at noon and useless in tunnels. She took a hard candy from the box, unwrapped it with fingers that did not tremble and held it out to Caelan as if to say you might not be allowed this, and I will enjoy seeing if you refuse. He put out his hand and she walked the steps between crate and angle of his wrist like someone who had learned to count to keep from drowning. She placed the candy in his palm with a precision that made you want to apologize for ever having been clumsy. He put it on his tongue without looking down, because he understood rites he had not invented.

Mara tried to find where the room’s hum lay without asking it to hum for her. Roe’s note tucked itself against her palate on instinct. The girl’s eyes moved; there was a river in them and also a city and neither felt proprietary about which parts belonged to whom. She took the tin of salt and let two grains fall onto the sugar diagram as if letting birds out of a pocket. The ash lifted very slightly, a contented animal repositioning. The girl smiled once, quick as a coin in a magician’s hand and as unhelpful to anyone trying to make a lesson of it.

“What are we calling you,” Kestrel asked, because names are knives and you hand people the handles you mean them to hold.

The girl put her finger through the ribbon at her wrist and pulled it tighter like a tourniquet made from sentiment. Her mouth shaped two sounds without letting sound out. She showed them to Mara the way you show someone a paper airplane right before you throw it. The shape of those mouth-movements mattered more than any letters that might get written. They were the vowels you make when you taste something you have never tasted that might be poisonous and you decide to finish anyway. Mara nodded as if she had been told, and repeated the shape, quieter. “Anise,” she said, and the girl’s mouth moved again in a way that admitted this was approximate and adequate and for the moment enough.

Caelan finished the candy and did not flinch at the generosity of a child who lives under a bridge giving a vampire sugar. He asked her with a care a man uses for dynamite and orphanages, “Anise, does the ash write back if you feed it. Do you teach it letters.”

Anise tilted her head half-over and you could imagine her once being told not to spill by a woman who was still alive then and did not use a kind voice for instructions. She held out her hand and asked for Mara’s with a glance that did not seek permission so much as to confirm a ritual. Mara stepped forward because the absence of fear is not a virtue, but refusing to perform it can be. Anise took Mara’s ring-hand in both of hers and turned it, palm up, with a delicacy that made the ring feel shy. She blew on the metal once like cooling a spoon. She touched the ash line with the tip of her smallest finger and then touched the ring and then touched her tongue, which was either how she called a god or how she proved to herself that they are not always bright. The ash lifted again, less a word than a breath that had been waiting to speak since before the Charter had been a set of clauses and not a song.

“It knows to knock,” Mara said, and Anise’s mouth made the shadow of a yes that didn’t want the work of being a yes. Roe’s note held the seam quiet this time the way a hand on the back of a child’s neck says don’t. Anise scattered three tiny cubes from the honey jar, sugar turned glass by a stove and a patience that had learned its edges burning itself. The ash made an O. Then a line. Then a lopsided spiral that made Kestrel whisper a profanity you only say when you realize the geometry you need is going to make your life longer and your sleep shorter.

“The old script,” Caelan said under his breath, and it sounded like a man reciting a catechism he pretended not to remember in case his mother were listening. “Not the letter for door. The letter for threshold.”

“Difference,” said Ran, who had a family that had never in its history let a distinction die of neglect. “A door belongs to the room. A threshold belongs to the house. You can break a door. You have to bribe a threshold.”

Anise touched Mara’s wrist again, quick, like please don’t look at this part in front of him. She made a motion with her head that could have meant leave or stay or bring me up where the air remembers the sky. Mara looked at Caelan and then at Kestrel and then at the ash and made a decision you could not revise once you made it. She nodded and said to Anise, “We’ll go up. Your choice of stairs. Then you can teach me if I am to sing so the threshold decides it would like me enough to not tell its friends later that I was rude.”

They found the easiest rung-ladder and took it like a prayer you don’t believe but rattles along the inside of your teeth anyway. The street above was the kind with four languages on the signage and washing hung like flags that meant we have survived and intend to continue. The river smell argued with frying and both lost. Anise squinted once, which was a thing she did not do underground, and then put a hand in Kestrel’s coat pocket without asking and came up with a piece of chalk Kestrel had not been aware of carrying because the city slips you tools when it wants to see what you will build. Anise wrote on the pavement a shape that would not have meant anything to a person from a place that had never heard what Quietites told themselves about stones. It looked like a house that had reconsidered and become a hand. It looked like a set of teeth that had not decided whether to smile.

Three children stopped mid-chase and watched her write as if a cart had overturned and spilled sugar in front of them. A woman with her wrists deep in dough at a ground-floor window leaned out with her elbows, a childhood she hadn’t realized she remembered appearing on her face and staying there without her permission. Pax, who had managed to arrive in spite of three mid-level executives with titles like Liaison attempting to intercept him so they could say they were useful to history by keeping it from being itself, kept his body where it looked theatrical to his enemies and supportive to his friends. The chalk made a sound like a small door opening in rooms where doors are only allowed to be decorative.

Anise finished the shape and put her fingertip to her tongue again and grinned for real, evil and childish and proud. All it did was lighten the air for one second the way a window lightens when a bird flies past. If you hadn’t been born here you would have missed it. If you had, you would remember it the way you remember that one day when you were six and someone you love laughed so loud you forgot to pretend to be shy.

“Show me what to sing at thresholds,” Mara said, and Anise shook her head and pointed at Mara’s mouth and then at her own and then at the chalk, which even Pax understood, which was that there are songs you write with breath and songs you write with your feet on stones. Anise took Mara’s hand and placed it on the drawn threshold and pressed until Mara could feel the grit come up into her palm like words that had not been spoken because no one had the right last night. Mara listened. The listening took a piece from her. She gave it and did not ask for change. She hummed the vowel Soria had given her and moved it three inches right because Anise tapped her wrist and you do what you’re told when a child who knows more than you do tells you to.

The chalk line did not glow because good magic in this city has terrible taste and refuses to make itself easy. It steadied. It felt like a floor deciding now would be an excellent time to hold.

In Annotations, Aron Tull sat at his desk and rolled a stamp across a bill of lading the way men smoke cigarettes when they are trying not to break a promise they made to themselves that morning. He looked up when the windows hummed, not with surprise but with that tired condescension some men think will keep magic from embarrassing them in front of their receipts. He had a file on his desk that said IVES, MARA—CUSTODY: DECLARATION and he did not touch it because touching things makes them feel invited, and he had learned to be careful which invitations were written in his hands.

In Marrowgate, Lale set three staplers in a row and told a room full of men with very particular resentments that sentences were not accountable for the men who used them badly. She gave Silas a sheaf of notices that needed writing and a time by which they needed to be written, which is a form of love available in only a few rooms. When the hum came through the building like a thought someone had remembered in the middle of an argument and did not want to admit was a good one, she turned her head toward the wall and let her face do two or three things before she put the face back she used for keeping men from throwing their pens. Silas put his hand on the seam with the matter-of-factness of a man checking a fever in the dark and felt it hold instead of wanting something from him. He kept writing because he had found that you can be more than one man at once if the work is the kind that keeps your hands in one place.

Edda took the pulp of the paper flower from the windowsill where it had dried into a stubborn, unattractive sheet and wrote a list on it, not because lists save the world but because lists on particular paper can be told what to do with their lives. Milk. Soap. Salt. A note to Soria that said Come by and bring me the gossip and I will feed you something you will pretend is not sweet. She folded the paper and did not think about the way her fingers learned a knot as she tied the string around it, a knot she had learned in a street when a man with a commendation pin had come to ask if her husband wanted to help the city be better and had not left until the soup was cold. She put the list in her pocket and went to the market with a determined normality that made three people on the stair rest their backs against the wall and breathe a breath they had not realized they were holding.

By late afternoon, when the glass buildings begin to believe they are lakes and everyone who has a pride makes the mistake of falling into it, the Division decided to stop pretending not to have noticed anything. They came to the south tunnels with the politeness of men trained to enter rooms without making the dust complain. Their inspector wore a coat with the peculiar, glossy grief of new leather and a badge that had not had time to learn its place on his chest. His name, like his tie, had been chosen by someone else and handed to him. He asked Caelan for access with sentences that had been approved by a lawyer who did not enjoy poetry. Caelan let him finish because he respected tactics and because refusing quickly is sometimes weaker than refusing slowly.

“The tunnels are not the business of men who write reports unless invited,” Caelan said, very politely, with the slight turn to the last word that made the inspector remember he had a stomach and a memory of being told not to go in water you could not see the bottom of. “Consider this a partial invitation. You may look where we look. You will not touch where we would not.”

The inspector made a note as if notes could force stone to become a paragraph. He said the word custodian because men in his building had decided to try it on the city’s throat. Pax, who had arrived specifically to prevent that word from getting any more exercise than necessary, laughed softly as if someone had told a joke that should have been better, and said the Charter does not create custodians of voices any more than it creates owners of rivers. He offered the inspector a sweet, because sometimes sugaring a mouth prevents it from saying things badly. The inspector declined because he had eaten today already and would not be bought for less than an ambition.

They walked together to the place where Anise had taught the ash to mind its manners with sugar and patience and the lack of adult supervision that does real miracles. Anise was gone of course, not because she was afraid but because you do not leave a child in a room once you know which men have learned the way to it, not even a room with ashes trained to draw ovals instead of knives. The inspector knelt and sniffed and immediately tried to make his face not confess how much joy sugar can carry even when it is on stone. He drew a circle with his pen and the ash did not indulge him. Ran coughed into her hand and did not say you are not a woman with a chalk; the ash is not interested in your little thoughts.

It would have been a manageable day of measured confrontations and narrowly averted errors if the city had not decided to show off in the one way it knows how. At the tail end of evening, when even the river blinks slow, the door appeared again, not under the bridge or in a switchyard but propped with great courtesy against the newly whitewashed wall of a school where girls had learned to slap hands in rhythm that made boys on the other side of the fence wonder what game they were missing. It hummed with an amiable presumption that made the chalk in Mara’s pocket vibrate against her leg. The custodians of that street were women with aprons and men with pennons because the school had a team that threw balls through rings and insulted other teams in songs they had learned from their grandmothers. They gathered at a curious, well-behaved distance around the door and did not touch it because touching things before you have decided whether you’re in love with them is a habit this city tries to beat out of you early.

Caelan came and did not touch it either. He put the back of his hand near the glass as if he might be asking it to be friends without asking for any of its time. The Girls’ Principal, a woman with a neck like a column and a voice you didn’t want to owe late homework to, folded her arms and said, “If that thing is going to ruin my wall, I will make a song out of its name and be very unkind to it.” Pax promised her money for paint whether the wall needed it or not. The principal said she would take new balls and a better net, because girls need something to throw at where their aim is not suspected.

Anise was there before any of them saw her, which is a trick only certain children learn and usually to their detriment. She touched the chalk line of threshold Mara had drawn that morning on a different street and moved it four finger-widths to the left, which would not have changed anything if the world were a place where precision was not magic. It changed everything there, the little bit that matters. The door’s hum softened. Roe’s note in Mara’s mouth went still and then changed key not because Roe told it to but because the door had decided it would rather be a friend than an opening.

“Whatever is behind it likes us,” Kestrel murmured, not comforted, exactly, by that fact. “Let’s not like it back until it pays rent.”

Mara did not sing. She put her palm against the glass because sometimes you cannot expect a city to allow you to be clever when you can be honest. The ring made a small heat. She did not pull her hand away because she had learned last night that sometimes pain is a conversation. “Not tonight,” she said softly, because her throat had learned that sentence from a man who refused to use it lightly, and then, because she was not him and because she had been taught by Soria and because Anise had made a chalk house out of a hand, she added, “But come talk through the wall. We are tired of monologues. Teach me your question instead of pushing with it.”

No one who had been to church wanted to write down what happened without cheapening it. The door did not open. The glass did not shatter. The hum took a more interesting shape. Mara felt along it the way you feel along a piano when you are learning which notes your grandmother sang when she did not know anyone was listening. She found there a sweetness that was not sugar and a stubbornness that was not ash. She felt a presence that was not a person and not not a person reading her hand the way women read fortunes and then looking up to see if her face belonged to the hand. It decided three things in a row about her and forgot the first two because the third was more interesting.

Silas woke at the exact moment the hum changed and put his pen down and put his hand against the seam and felt the seam answer in a thickness that did not belong to stone. He spoke without saying anything because words would make a mess. Somewhere in a room without a wall, a door leaned toward the place his voice would be if his throat were allowed to be its own animal, and then leaned back because it had been taught caution by engineers long dead and girls who draw houses with chalk.

The Division’s inspector wrote the words anomalous artifact in his book as if the book had asked for this sentence as a reward. He asked for the door to be taken into custody. The Girls’ Principal made a sound that meant not while I am here. Pax asked him if he would like to be photographed saying the word custody at an object women and children were standing near with their palms open and their hands honest. Caelan noted how the shadow at the base of the frame lengthened in a way that belonged to a room that did not exist in the world and kept his body between the door and the crowd with a stillness that is what courage looks like before and after banners.

Anise took Mara’s wrist again and guided her hand down a fraction the way you show someone the proper placement of a thread through a needle. Mara let the hand-hum go slack and then taut and then slack again and the door’s humming settled into a stave Roe would later be able to write down in a notation that would make other engineers happy and annoyed. The moment passed the way traffic passes and leaves you alone with the knowledge that all those other lives are going somewhere you can neither prevent nor assist.

After, in the hush that always looks like a dignity but is actually relief being too tired to do anything else, Soria arrived carrying a towel and a bag of bread ends that had been soaking in milk and onions since yesterday. She took one look at the number of men whose mouths had opinions and the number of girls who had stopped pretending not to watch and said, as if she were introducing herself to a room full of misbehaving soap, “We will need bowls. We will need to sit down. We will need to make the street a kitchen now before it becomes a kind of theater worse than any we can write ourselves.”

They did. The Girls’ Principal had bowls because girls always need them; bread requires them and so does blood. Soria tore the bread and ladled stew and put a bowl in Mara’s hands like a benediction and shoved another at the inspector so that he could not say the word custody with his mouth full. Caelan took one and ate with a soldier’s gratitude, which is to say he ate as if he might not get to again and would not complain if someone interrupted him with a war. Pax ate and licked his thumb and said he could write a law that would codify bread in streets during incidents as a required line item, and Soria told him she would take his tie instead.

When it was almost dark, when the ash under the bridge wrote O one more time and then forgot how to finish its second letter because a child somewhere was asleep, when a door had leaned and decided it would come back to find out whether anyone in this city knew how to answer a question without making it a sermon, when the Division had gone home and written a report they tried to convince themselves did not make them frightened in their suits, Mara stood with Anise at the edge of the water and let the river breathe on her face. Anise reached into the sack of sugar and drew a line on the stone so thin even the river pretended it didn’t notice. She put the last hard candy from the box into Mara’s mouth because there are certain favors between girls that do not require signatures. Mara let it break and let the sweetness hurt and then melt because survival is often a series of small decisions to let something dissolve rather than spit it out.

“You could come home with me,” Mara said softly, knowing what the answer was and saying it anyway because hospitality is not a trick; it is a vow that makes you bigger. Anise shook her head and looked in the direction of the old Baths and then the tunnels and then the bridge as if to say I am home in too many places to choose and your walls will feel narrow and you will think it is about me when it is about your walls. She tapped the ring and then tapped Mara’s forehead in the exact place Edda tapped when she was trying to correct a thought without naming it. She pointed at Kestrel and mimed eyeliner with her thumb and forefinger and made a face that meant you need a wall with a mouth who can talk at men while you look for the seam, and then she laughed without sound and ran because running is still a freedom in this city and some girls refuse to be cured of it.

Night came with its crooked halo and the city pretended for three hours that it was normal to hum through the windows of people who had done nothing to deserve it. The billboards failed again slowly in a way that made them endearing. The Lancers made the kind of jokes they make when the enemy is, for the moment, smarter than they want it to be. The Friends of Music wrote three notes on a wall and rubbed them away with steam so that only the tile remembered. Roe slept and dreamed of cats standing on knobs and refused to tell anyone because she would never be done being mortified by joy. The Lord Governor wrote citizen in a speech and for once did not cross it out. Aron Tull put his head in his hands in a room full of files and said aloud, to no one and to the part of himself that might yet be interesting, “We do not own doors,” and then wrote it down because words make cowards brave when they believe they can read them later and pretend it was always their idea.

Edda laid two spoons on the table and rolled her eyes when the cat pretended not to want to stand on the chair and then stood anyway with the innate rightness of cats. She tasted the stew and swore under her breath about lava and love. She listened for her daughter’s step and felt the ring from across the room the way you feel thunder coming in your molars when you are old enough to have learned to count between flash and sound. She put a plate of bread under a dishcloth and said to the kitchen, which had never betrayed her and never would, “If the door wants in, it learns to knock. We are not barbarians.”

Silas wrote his three paragraphs and the joke Lale would like and a line on his own wall, in chalk, that would wash in the morning: I am not a door. He sat with his back to the seam and did not pretend to be brave, which made him more useful than he had been in years to something he could not name. He thought of a girl’s ring tapping his forehead and what would have happened in a corridor if someone had knocked and someone else had answered instead of barging and ending.

On the parapet Caelan looked at the dark and thought about thresholds and the men he had lost who shouldn’t have had to be brave that night, and the girls who built new vowels out of old chalk, and the way a door had behaved better than most men. He let the night stand next to him and did not ask it for anything and it liked him better for that. He thought that he would tell Mara tomorrow the names of every part of a bridge you never put on a map because men think bridges are simple and thus break them with confidence. He thought he would tell her what you paid and how to make sure you paid only once. Then he stopped thinking for a measured quarter hour and let his body count a rhythm that had nothing to do with drums or boots or the turnstiles in his ribs when he put on armor, and everything to do with the way a city breathes when it has been allowed to believe itself for one day.

Morning would bring another audit, another door, another seam refusing to explain itself like a gallant. It would bring Deputy Pell counting her own mercy and Anise making a line thinner than a thought. It would bring Pax’s tie being stolen and returned, and Soria’s bath a degree too hot on purpose so that girls would remember their edges. It would bring an old boy with a broken shield writing a letter to a song he didn’t like and didn’t know how to live without. It would bring the river doing what rivers do, which is carry you away if you stand still and carry you away if you move. It would bring paint for the school wall because girls always win when paint is involved. It would bring the sovereign made of ash deciding if he could be offended by something that had not been meant for him and trying anyway. It would bring Edda cutting paper she had made into squares and drawing boxes in which to put the words she didn’t intend to write, and then writing them and letting the cat judge her.

For the moment, there was breath. There was soup. There were doors that did not own you. There was sugar in stone and chalk under a child’s fingernail and a ring behaving, for the space of a sleeping house, like jewelry. There were Lancers waiting to become monsters you could pray for again, which is the city’s oddest blessing, and singers learning to say Not tonight with enough vowels to make it hold. There were bad men with paper flowers on their jackets going home to mirrors that could not be persuaded to become doors. There were good women with pockets with knives and tools and sweets, and their pockets will be written about later by clever men pretending they discovered them, and that will be fine because those men will be very entertained by their own work and the women will still be alive. There were names on walls and names in throats and names that were not yet names but would come when someone knocked and somebody else, for once, will deserve to be the one to answer.

At dusk the city’s teeth came out. Copper roofs and black spires, banners hissing like serpents in the wind. Eydolon balanced between its two Declares—the Treaty of Red and the Charter of Sound—while the Night Lancers massed in their marble barracks like patient thunder. People pretended not to notice the vampires striding down the lantern avenues with shields like broken moons. People pretended a lot of things after the Ash Wars. That was how you lived here. Pretend, then nod, then watch. Some of us sang. Or we tried.

Mara Ives stood in the queue outside the Glass District’s third-most-important recording house, Hollow Sun, and tried not to scratch at the faded itch on her left hand. The sigil there had never quite gone away, a ghost of warmth beneath her knuckles, as if ink that wasn’t ink had sunk down into the veins. It had showed up when she was seven and had been, at the time, a crescent the colour of tea. Now it was a whisper. She curved her fingers to hide it and felt silly for caring.

“You going in or not?” said the girl behind her, eyeliner like a storm.

Mara shuffled forward. The line jerked, a chorus of nervous laughter rose and fell, someone dropped a bottle cap and it rolled forever. Above them, a billboard flashed: ANTHEMS FOR A NEW EYDOLON. A fang-white smile, a male soloist with hair like lacquer. The tag line: We Don’t Do Ballads, We Do Blood.

“First time?” the eyeliner girl asked.

“Not exactly,” Mara lied, even though everything about her was first time. First time in the Glass District at night without her mother. First time in a queue where the front of the room was a panel of A&Rs linked to Night Lancer rotations. First time wearing boots her father would have called impractical for running.

The girl gave her a once-over. “Cute jacket. You look like you don’t want to be here. Always a help.”

“I want to be here,” Mara said, and swallowed. Her throat was dry. “I just—my mother says if I get chosen I’ll need to sleep during the day and she can’t stand people sleeping during the day. The light offends her.”

“Does your mother eat soup with a fork too?” said the girl, and then grinned before turning away to scroll a mirror into existence with her thumb. A privacy charm shimmered, then faded.

Mara’s phone vibrated. A message from her mother shot to the top of the screen: back by third bell. no deals with men in coats. if they offer food don’t take it unless you watch them cook it. call me if your feet hurt i’ll tell you to sit down. love.

She typed, i am not five. also my feet are fine. also love.

Her mother’s typing bubble appeared immediately. you’re never not five.

The queue twitched again and the heavy glass doors breathed. Inside: a cruise ship of a lobby, crisscrossed by gold escalators and humming with the kind of music that eats its own tail. Mara clutched her zippered portfolio, which held a handful of song scraps written in cramped pencil: sticky pop hooks that came to her like embroidery, and two ballads she would never show these people in a million years because they were about grief and aftertaste and the sound of the cellar when the wind was under it. Grief didn’t sell. Eydolon only wanted songs they could chant in unison in the combat tunnels, layered atop the march-steps of the Night Lancers.

She had come because a friend—okay, the eyeliner girl’s cousin—had said the A&R director himself, Pax Lumen, could grant an audience with the Lancer Lord. She had come because the Charter of Sound had returned to public fashion, and the city wanted a saint with a pop chorus.

And she had come because the ring had sung to her in the kitchen two nights ago, and she had spent forty minutes pretending it was the faucet squealing, and then an hour not breathing at all.

That ring lay in her pocket, wrapped in a napkin, wrapped in superstition. It was the wrong colour for silver, the wrong weight for glass. Her mother had called it a tourist trinket when it arrived in the post, no sender, no note. Mara had snorted and put it in a drawer. Then the crows knew her name, and every time she walked under the viaduct the pigeons paused.

The line burbled forward. The guard at the door took her name like a thief. Inside, the chill of money. The lobby wall shimmered with a slow loop of Night Lancers training in the rain, gear spinning, swords collapsing into baton-like rods. A tagline scrolled beneath: WE WERE MONSTERS. NOW WE’RE YOURS.

A man folded himself from a couch nearby, lifting a scarf. He looked like a story about youth written by someone who’d never been young. A scar chiseled his cheekbone.

“Pax Lumen,” said the eyeliner girl under her breath, as if spitting out a fruit seed. “Careful—he with the bright teeth.”

Pax scanned the room like a lighthouse. He always knew when someone was pretending. His gaze snagged on Mara and held, like a thumb on a string.

“You,” he said. “Mara Ives?”

She nodded. “Yes, sir.”

He winced. “Don’t do that to me. I’m not the one with gloves. Come upstairs. I’ve got ten minutes before the Command Council calls me for another lecture on tone.”

She could feel every eye in the lobby snap to her back as she followed. There were whispers, the word ring, she thought she heard. Or she thought she hoped someone had finally said it out loud so it wasn’t just hers to carry, a foolish thing and a dangerous thing both. Pax moved like a man who never worried about what his back looked like to anybody.

He took her through a hallway of dark wood and colder music, past doors that breathed sound, past a wall of framed gold discs and silver helmets. He opened a door at the end with a palm and ushered her into a chamber that felt like a deep-bellied instrument. A low table. A couch that tried to be seductive. Floor-to-ceiling windows showing the war barracks across the river, their steady lights.

“You know why I pulled you,” Pax said, and didn’t make it a question.

Mara shook her head. “No.”

“You’re honest. That makes this briefly easier.” Pax leaned his elbows on his knees. He had a dimple and the tired eyes of a man who has held too many funerals. “Tell me about the song in your kitchen.”

Mara closed her eyes because embarrassment was easier to manage in the dark. She folded her hands together, thumb over thumb, as if praying. “There was a…tone. Not a melody, not at first. A hum, only it wasn’t coming from anywhere. It was…being wavelengths, you know? It’s not a good explanation.”

“It’s a perfect explanation,” Pax said, and his voice was a little softer. “What did you do?”

“I told myself it was a pipe. And then—” She groped for the right stupidity. “I put on water to boil. I touched the ring. Just to, I don’t know. Test it and get it over with. It burned. But not like burning. Like cold. Like I could see my hands light up without them really doing it.” Mara opened her eyes. “Do you think—my mother says there are devices for that. Prank rings.”

Pax laughed, and it was like an engine misfiring. “Sure, and sometimes the moon is a paper lantern hung by a kindly God so the children won’t be scared. Do you have it?”

Mara hesitated. “What happens if I do?”

Pax shrugged. “Then I perhaps offer you a job. And someone else in a different building has an easier time sleeping because they know the Charter is not a relic. And eventually, if you consent, the vampires swing their batons just a little cleaner because the city’s song is a live wire again instead of a museum piece.”

“My consent?” she said, too sharp.

His smile flicked. “That part is real. There are, however, civic urgencies. The Lancers can’t compel a cantor. Not anymore. The wars ruined that sort of convenience in us. But the ring—and I suspect you know this even if you don’t know how you know—likes to be used. It doesn’t enjoy drawers.”

Slowly, as if she were negotiating with a wild animal, Mara pulled the napkin bundle from her pocket and set it on the table. Pax didn’t reach for it. He waited. The napkin’s threads trembled under her fingers. She unwound it. The ring lay like a small planet on the cloth: pale metal with flecks of something like ash beneath its translucent surface, a lens with a darkness at the center, as if it had been made to see through time to water and ruin.

Pax’s mouth pressed thin. “I thought it would be ugly,” he said. “Everyone always says it was the most beautiful thing they’ve ever held, because that’s the only way they can justify what it asks. But I think—I think honesty might be the new glamour.”

“It’s not mine,” Mara said quickly. “It just arrived. No one told me. I only, I haven’t—”

He held up a hand. “The ring is nobody’s. It chooses a throat and a heart. The old stories say it was forged in the last days of the Quietites by a woman who promised that sound could shape a city if it were honest and ungentle enough. The Night Lancers of Oris have always listened for it. But the ring goes where it goes. It found you. It passed through hands to find you. That isn’t theft. It’s how fate misbehaves.”

Fate misbehaves, she thought, and then—“You didn’t ask my age.”

Pax blinked. “I read your file. You turned twenty last winter. Your mother made a pistachio-cheery cake; I am jealous.”

“I mean—” She flushed. It was ridiculous. “There are rumours. That the ring requires…purity.”
