He looked at her as if she were telling him he was a fish. “Ignorance is purity,” he said. “Not stupid, mind you. Untethered. Uncontext. The ring needs a throat that hasn’t been taught to steady itself for convenience. People think virginal means flesh. It’s not that. It’s an unused vow. It’s a person who hasn’t yet promised away their voice. You’ve never signed a contract, not even at the open mic level. You’ve never bent yourself to suit a room, I can hear it when you speak. There are edges. The ring likes edges.”

Mara exhaled and felt a little dizzy. “So it’s not—that.”

“Not that,” he said, his tone rueful. “Though I cannot stop a city from making up stories to entertain itself.”

He slid the ring closer to her with one knuckle. She didn’t pick it up. She wasn’t sure whether she wanted to leave the room or throw the windows open and scream. The weight in the air was heavy with potential and the memory of rain.

“Listen,” Pax said. “We’re going to do this carefully. There will be contracts but they will not own you. The Lancers will take your measure but they will not taste you. The city will press itself against your face but you may say no. The Charter of Sound is clear, despite what the old men on the Council think. You release one song. Just one. A pop song. It’s a rite, it’s a—call it a broadcast. It resonates through the wards. We need it to wake the Gates. And after that you decide if you’re a singer or if you’re just a particular miracle, once.”

“How much time do I have?” Her voice trembled. “I’m—my mother will make onion soup. She’ll expect me at the table.”

“Listen to you,” he said softly. “The sound of a city that has not yet got hold of you. Time—we have none. Or we have hours. There is a reconnaissance report at dusk. The Ash Sovereign is stirring again. The Lancers will march before dawn if they must. Your song could tilt the night. No pressure. Tea after. Onion soup before morning if you insist.”

He sat back and the room exhaled with him. Mara looked at the ring and saw—not a future, no, but a hundred half-futures. All of them had music in them, and in some of them she was free at the end. In others she wasn’t. Her stomach did something unwise.

“Okay,” she said. Then, again, like an oath. “Okay.”

In Marrowgate Prison, in a cell that had seen five names burn into the door and fade, a man wrote a sentence, crossed it out, and wrote it again. The sentence was about a woman who had never been born. He called her by names that tasted like the river in winter. He was a killer if you asked the city and also if you asked the ledger. There was very little to argue about. His name was Silas Brune and he had made a choice twelve years ago that made the world narrower. There had been a boy and a corridor and a blade that fit a hand that seemed too ready. The story in the papers had been efficient. The story in his head never shut up.

Silas wrote: In another life I make masks instead of knives. In another life the city of Eydolon is all round windows and red clay and you can plant lavender on the roofs. In another life there are no Night Lancers because there is no night.

He stopped and laughed, and the laugh wasn’t a nice thing. It shook out of him like a cough. The guard on the far end of the tier glanced up and then down again. Silas dipped his pen. The prison library had given him four sheets of real paper for the week, which was a kindness they told him he was wasting. He wasted them anyway. He thought about the girl he had seen once at the edge of a crowd when they brought the vampires back from the southern gates with broken shields: she had a look that made your hunger stop. Not pity. Not worship. He thought maybe if he wrote her, the alternative would write itself, and in that other city he did not make a corridor dim with the end of someone.

He wrote: In this alternative, there is a ring made of a window that was shattered without sound. It makes songs. You think you cannot imagine that? I cannot imagine much else anymore.

The paper received it, sallow and patient. He held the pen poised. He liked to think he could make a different world if he wrote fast enough. He liked to think he had been in jail all along, even before the cell. Inside the sentence. Inside the knife. Writing the story of a life he didn’t get to live. A man must build a room and live in it when the city refuses one.

He closed his eyes and saw a kitchen. He didn’t know why. He saw a young woman with a beautiful ignorance and a napkin she wouldn’t unwrap at first. He wrote her singing, though he had never heard her voice.

The Night Lancers rode past Hollow Sun at dusk as Mara stood in front of the studio microphone and tried not to vomit. The glass room was a cathedral. The boards under her boots had been polished by the fear of a hundred voices. Pax Lumen stood in the booth with two techs, an old witch of a sound engineer named Roe, and a vampire with eyes like a paper cut.

The vampire wore his crest over a simple black shirt: a narrow shield with an iron tree. He looked like a man who lost his temper and then wrote apology notes in calligraphy. He said his name was Caelan Varro, in a voice like metal singing.

“The Lord of the Night Lancers,” Pax had said when they shook hands, as if she’d wandered into a fable with the wrong shoes on.

Caelan Varro did not overstare her. He had the discipline of a man who believed that restraint could hold a city together. He waited. He did not smile because smiling at a girl when you are a vampire carries a thousand wrong meanings and he wasn’t interested in any of them.

“Do you hum?” Roe asked. “Before you sing? Some singers do, some don’t. Some pray.”

“I count,” Mara said. “But quietly.”

“Count then,” Roe said, turning a dial. “Count us a road to walk you down.”

Mara counted, lips parted but no sound at first. She counted the way she had as a child, when a storm broke the sky and she had to pretend that numbers were stones, reliable and breathable. She counted to seven, because seven was where you could stop if you had to and say you were only tuning and not failing.

Pax pressed the talk-back button. “Whenever you’re ready. Remember, it doesn’t have to be good. It has to be true. Pop is just truth with a beat.”

“That’s the same thing,” Roe said grumpily, and turned another dial.

Mara looked at the ring on her finger for the first time as something owned. It didn’t fit so much as adapt, subtly adjusting in minuscule sighs. She swallowed. She lifted her hands because something in her wanted to summon or push away or both. She wanted her mother, who would stand next to her and put a palm on her back and say, This is going to hurt but it’s going to be ours.

Across the glass, Caelan Varro watched her with a tactical attention that should have been terrifying and wasn’t. There was something in it that recognized her, as if he had been waiting at different doors his whole long life and here was the one with someone behind it.

She sang a single note first, and it broke.

She laughed, and the laugh sounded like chalk down a slate. It startled her. She tried again. The second note found a place to sit.

“Again,” Pax said gently.

She let the ring warm. She thought of the kitchen and the faucet yelling. She thought of the pigeons listening. She thought of the city’s teeth. She thought of what it meant to not promise yourself away yet. She opened her mouth and a melody came that wasn’t careful. It jittered, it hopped, it refused to be elegant. But the words fell into it like stones into a steady river, splashing, making rings.

“I am a wire,” she sang, and the line surprised her. “I am a voice on fire. You don’t know my name yet, but you will by the morning light—”

Her boots found the beat because Roe found it first and laid it down under her, a thump like a door opening. Pax held up a hand and the tech muttered “Live,” and the red light went on that meant the city could be invited if you wanted. We do this as a private rite first, Pax had said, and if it holds, we send it through the Gate towers, we feed it to the rails. The ring would decide too. That was the part that was both fair and not.

“I’m a blade not drawn yet, I’m a vow you haven’t heard,” said the next line, and she wanted to argue with herself about being melodramatic but the melody knocked all argument down. “I won’t be quiet, no, I won’t be—quiet you—quiet you—”

The ring threw sparks on the inside of her knuckles. It showed her the city’s map flipped inside out. It showed her the river walking. The air in the studio thickened with math.

In the booth, Roe swore in a useful way and pulled two channels down. Pax was grinning now, not in triumph but in relief so honest it stung to see. Caelan Varro inclined his head, and the small movement had the weight of a vow.

“Keep it dirty,” Roe said into the talk-back. “Don’t polish. Pop hates clean. Pop wants the thing that almost fell out of your mouth.”

Mara nodded, a small soundless yes. She did not think the words. She let the drum do the thinking. She let herself say it like a dare to every corridor she had ever walked without looking up.

“I am the ring and I am the finger,” she sang, and Pax twitched because he had wanted to skip that, ancient and on the nose and maybe wrong. But the ring wanted it and she wanted it and the two of them together were not interested in a marketing plan.

“If you touch me you’ll remember,” she sang, and then it went sideways into light. The chord she chose should not have fit. It slid off the beat like a glass on a wet table. And then it found a groove that had been waiting under the city for years, the one that made people breathe on the offbeat. It was a pop song, glitzy and shameless, and the power in it didn’t come from shame or red hunger. It came from the audacity of saying: we are here, we are ridiculous and venomous and brave, we are going to dance while we strap on armor.

Pax hit the button that said Send. It was small and he had sworn he would wait. But the room felt bigger now than a room. The walls were more perforation than wall. The city wanted the song as much as the song wanted the city. He pressed and the lightning went forth.

In Marrowgate, Silas Brune heard the hum through stone. It tickled his ear and made his pen skip. He sat up, slow, like a dog in a new house. He had heard a thousand sounds in that prison, water dividing itself, the whisper of a rat designing a universe, the long rope of scar tissue that was a man’s snore. He had never heard this. It was like someone plucked a thread that ran through him twenty miles away.

He wrote: In another life, I do not kill him. In another life, I hear this song earlier.

He went to the bars and pressed his forehead to the cold. The guard looked up and then looked away. There was the tiniest smile trying its foolish luck at the corner of Silas’s mouth. He let it. He wasn’t sure whether it was his.

In Eydolon, the Gate towers drank the song. Music bloomed along the rails, ran down into the tunnels, bounced off the shields at the training grounds, slipped into the pockets of civilians like a charm slipped into a hand. People stopped mid-step. In the bakery on Bridge Street, a woman with flour on her knuckles put down the proofing basket and laughed. In the barracks, soldiers looked at each other with the stranded expression of someone remembering how to be happy and not liking the suddenness of it. The Ash flicker along the far walls of the city guttered and steadied. Above the floodgates, the old runes breathed.

Caelan closed his eyes and let the song pass through him. He was old enough to remember the last time a Charter Song had been done properly, before the Councils fractured and the Church lost its mirror. That had been a boy’s voice, as sharp as new gin. This one was a woman’s voice. It got itself dirty. It made a promise it might regret. He liked that. Cities needed regret as much as they needed teeth.

He opened his eyes and saw Pax looking at him, and something like a conversation passed between them without a word. There would be trouble. There were always rumours when a man like Pax pressed the red button earlier than the men with medals liked. There would be the matter of consent, of the Charter’s clauses. There would be the old wives with their old complaints and the new wolves with their new strategies. There would be, above all, the Ash Sovereign’s answer.

Mara sang a last line that wasn’t part of the plan, because there had never been a plan except the ring’s and hers, and then she stopped because it was correct to stop. The final syllable hung like a drop of resin, then hardened.

Silence in the studio was elegant. It did not apologize for itself.

Mara took the ring off and put it on the table. Her hands were trembling. She had sweat through the cute jacket. She had never felt more tired or more proud or more terrified.

Pax exhaled so gently you could have mistaken it for man trying not to cry. He clicked the button and said, “I’ll be gentle now, and then later I’ll go be un-gentle to the men with chairs. You did it.”

“I did a song,” Mara said, dazed. She did not quite yet feel the city hearing her. She felt doorways. She felt the electric after of a kiss she hadn’t had.

Roe came out and hugged her awkwardly from one side. Caelan did not move, which was his hug. Pax did what he always did when he loved someone a little: he arranged a bottle of water three inches closer.

“You need a statement,” Pax said. “They will ask why a Charter Song is also a pop song and you will tell them the Charter never said a song had to wear a robe.”

Mara laughed, burned out and high. “Do I get to go home after this?”

Pax’s smile folded. “Yes. For tonight. A car will take you. And a guard.”

“I don’t need—” She stopped when Caelan raised an eyebrow.

“You did a thing that changes the light in the city,” Caelan said. “You will take a guard so that fools feel deterred from using the dark to rearrange you.”

“Rearrange me,” she repeated, and almost grinned. “That’s polite.”

“We are very polite when we are about to scare people,” Caelan said, and the corners of his mouth did a peculiar, almost human thing. “I will walk you to the car.”

The elevator ride down was an elongated breath. Mara looked at the neon of the Glass District smeared on the doors. Her phone was vibrating again. She thought of her mother’s onion soup and almost wept. She thought of Silas Brune and didn’t know why she thought of him, a name that was a news story, a monster behind a headline, a man who lived at the fringe of every cautionary tale in Eydolon. The ring had showed her a corridor for a moment while she sang. It had been darker than any hallway she’d ever been in. There had been a feeling of someone unsaying his life.

“Will it hurt?” she asked without meaning to ask it out loud.

Caelan tilted his head. “Will what?”

“Being this. Doing that again.”

“Yes,” he said, not unkind. “But that is—life. And the ring does not like liars.”

She felt stupid tears gather. “I don’t want to be—owned by it. Or by anyone. I don’t want to end up one of those, you know, cautionary.”

“Then you must be very busy being otherwise,” Caelan said. “There is not much else to do about being a cautionary tale except refuse to end when the story says you ought to.”

The elevator opened into the lobby and the world rushed at them. The song had been out for nine minutes and the Glass District was a tongue. People were filming. People were crying. People pretended again and then failed at pretending. Mara felt invisible and too visible simultaneously. A child with red hair stared at her with a concentration that pinned butterflies to boards.

She almost asked Pax to hold her hand. He would have. But she did not. She walked shoulder to shoulder with a vampire lord instead and it made her feel ridiculous, and strong, and like a rumor in her own bones.

In Marrowgate, Silas put his hand against the concrete and whispered, “In another life I hold a thread that is not a throat.”

“You talking to the wall, Brune?” the guard said, bored more than unkind.

“Writing,” Silas said, and the guard laughed exactly once and then looked like he regretted it.

He lay down with his arm over his face and tried to dream an alternative where the song had come before the boy in the corridor. He didn’t get there. He got instead a window he couldn’t see out of and the sense of someone speaking on the other side, very close.

At home in a small apartment that smelled like thyme and laundry, Edda Ives set out two bowls and stirred a pot with a spoon that had belonged to her mother. She had the news on. She had a panicked cat pretending to be indifferent under the table. She felt the song when it passed down the wall. She stopped stirring and put her hand to her chest and said, “Oh.”

Her daughter was a woman, yes, and also—still a ridiculous child who had once tried to teach the kettle to purr. Edda hoped the city deserved her for one night. It often did not deserve anything for longer than that.

Mara sat in the back of the car and counted again. Seven. She looked at the ring on the seat beside her where she had set it, as if it were a passenger prone to carsickness. Caelan sat across from her like a story told to furniture. Pax was on the phone in the front seat saying, “Yes, but listen, it worked. Yes, I know the Charter. I can read. No, I will not tell her to wear white.”

There was a siren slice somewhere and then quiet again. Eydolon wore the song now like a wet dress, clinging and cold, revealing. Mara wondered if she would be recognized at the market, buying cucumbers, next week. She wondered if any of this would be a market next week.

She had wanted to be smaller than this. She had wanted to make songs that were silly and made girls put glitter on their cheeks in bathrooms. She had wanted to be the person who knew all the songs but not the person who wrote the ones that moved rivers. She had wanted the ring to be a prank. And yet now that it wasn’t, something inside her uncrossed its arms and said, Fine. Let’s find out who I am if I can’t wriggle out of this.

“Do the Night Lancers like pop?” she said, just to see Caelan’s face.

He met her joke with a straight answer. “They like whatever carries them through the nonnegotiable darkness between here and where they must be. Some of them pretend not to. Some of them write letters to the songs they pretend not to like.”

“What do you like?” She knew she should stop. She wasn’t going to stop.

“Drums,” he said. “And unembarrassed singing. And the silence after a victory that was not expected. And onion soup.”

Mara blinked. “I’m starting to like you, and I think that’s a mistake.”

“It is,” he said. “We are untrustworthy. But we are honest about it, which confuses people.”

The car turned left where it should have turned right and the driver apologized without being told to. Pax was off the phone now and looking at two devices at once, his hands making the kind of motion that calms tech and inflames men who want to be calm. The city outside the window was its own armour: bridges like rib bones, corners like elbows, the river carrying on.

“Your mother will hate me,” Pax said.

“She’ll bring you soup,” Mara said. “It will change your life.”

“I have a life,” Pax said, which may have been a joke.

She watched the night. She watched her future walk next to the car like a stranger who kept pace uninvited. She closed her eyes and saw the song. She opened them and saw a woman on a balcony with her hands over her mouth. She saw a group of kids hanging out of a window with their phones held up, the screen glow like secret fires. She saw a man on a step who had chosen not to go inside just yet in case the song asked him to.

“Tomorrow,” Pax said, “we do the part where we argue that the Charter is not a museum display. And you do the part where you breathe and try to sleep. And I go to the Tower and tell the Lord Governor that if he uses the word maiden I will bite him.”

“Please do,” Mara said, tired and evil.

The car pulled up to her building, old brick like bread crust. Caelan stepped out first and looked at the roofline as if roofs told him stories. To her right, a shadow moved in the alley and then decided not to be a problem. The ring sat on the seat between them like an answer nobody had asked yet.

“Keep it,” Caelan said when he saw her look. “Don’t leave it on tables. Rings are famous for getting bored and leaving when you make them wait.”

“I wasn’t going to—I was.”

He picked the ring up with two fingers. It glinted and his lip curled the tiniest degree, like something that had a taste he didn’t expect. He handed it to her. The metal was warm. It took her back like a cat that wasn’t angry enough to stay gone.

“Thank you for the guard deterring fools,” she said, with more sincerity than she had expected to have.

He bowed, an old-world thing that should have looked ridiculous and didn’t. “We are very good at frightening fools. It is our most civic denomination.”

Then he left because a vampire lord should not be in your stairwell when you are about to hug your mother. Pax squeezed her shoulder like the man he wasn’t allowed to be in public and said, “Sleep, little miracle. The city will still be rude in the morning.”

Mara went upstairs. She knocked the three knocks that said I’m not a stranger and I’m not the landlord. Her mother opened the door and then there was soup and a cat and a chair and a short silence like a blanket. Her phone was still vibrating on the table. She put it face down. The world could be loud outside. Inside, there was onion and bread and the two of them not pretending for a minute that any of this was normal.

“My girl,” Edda said, and used a word that was completely denuded of childishness.

“I didn’t know if I could,” Mara said, and didn’t specify.

“You did,” Edda said, as if that solved anything and maybe it did. She put her hand on Mara’s forehead and then, like a woman casting a spell she had no training for, tapped the ring once with her knuckle. The ring made the tiniest noise, heard only by two women and a cat.

Later, when the building slept and the city wore stranger faces, Mara stood at her window and looked at the river. She touched the pane. She imagined she could see where the magic ran, like veins in a wrist. She thought of a man in a prison writing an alternative life that included her. She thought of vampires as warriors who would be at the bridge at dawn, bearing people’s songs like armour. She thought of promises and of refusing to be rearranged. She thought of being a particular miracle, once.

She hummed, hardly more than breath. The ring didn’t answer. It had done enough for one day. It lay against her skin and behaved like a piece of jewelry.

At Marrowgate, Silas dreamed of balconies and laughter and a river unbraiding itself. He woke to the thin light of almost morning and the sound of his own voice saying into the stale air, “In another life, I choose not to choose the knife.”

For once, the room was kind enough not to echo him. Outside, the Night Lancers lined up in disciplined geometry. Caelan Varro looked down the rank of his warriors and thought, Our city has a voice again. He did not know yet what price it would be. He only knew that the song had threaded their nights together with a string that would make it harder for them to forget one another in the dark.

In a world where the vampires were the ones you prayed for when the shadows moved, a girl who had not yet promised away her throat had released a pop song using a magic ring, and the city pretended and then stopped pretending and then danced in place. Somewhere a killer wrote a better life. Somewhere, someone waited for dawn as if dawn were a person they might love. The river carried on. The Gates breathed. The soup cooled. The song replayed whether you wanted it to or not. And above the Glass District, the billboards tried to catch up with what had already happened and failed, slowly, with such human precision it almost made them endearing.

Morning in Eydolon wore its halo crooked and pretended not to be tired. The river made the sort of noise a person makes when they find out they have to go to work again. Smoke from the bread ovens came up slow and silver, and every cornice wore a little dew like sweat. The city’s billboards were late to the party; they still showed hot faces from last night’s releases, a boy with lacquer hair and a fang-white smile, a drink brand pretending to be a revolution. Between them, the Gate towers did their own kind of advertising: a faint pulse along the old Quietite runes, a beating that made pigeons rotate on their ledges and steeple spiders move their webs three inches left like they knew something about geometry and fate.

Caelan Varro stood at the edge of the east drill field and watched his Lancers go through the first forms. Their boots struck in time to a rhythm the city had given them, and he did not correct that. He let his officers make the small noises that made the discipline hold, that kept men attached to their bodies when they wanted to drift into song and leave their edges behind. He had slept an hour and a half in a chair with a square back that tried to reduce him; it didn’t, and after he woke he felt a little like he had been sanded and then polished with river grit.

He listened to the reports from the night face him out of other men’s mouths. There had been a disturbance by the Third Gate, a scuffing like a door trying to decide whether to be polite. There had been a gathering in the Glass District that started as happiness and threatened for a twitching moment to become a riot, because joy made people brave as often as it made them fools. One of the western rails had vibrated hard enough that a man on the platform had dropped his coffee and swore an oath to the sort of god who accepted oaths about coffee. The north riverlight flickered once without wind. And someone had nailed a copy of the Charter of Sound to the door of a flower shop with bright pins, as if to say, Remember, this is not yours alone.

His adjutant, a woman whose hair had gone white on the forward edge first and who wore it cropped to make the most of the white, handed him two pages of paper that had been pressed flat with palm and ring. He took them because he dealt in paper almost as often as he dealt in war, and he read them while his Lancers finished the sequence that put their bodies into the shape of a promise.

The first paper was a schedule he had no chance of honoring. The second was a summary of the Lord Governor’s feelings about last night in language carefully shaved of profanity. The Lord Governor wanted the word maiden used in three separate statements and had been advised by three separate staffers not to. Caelan laughed to himself, and the laugh was like a small stone skipped across his ribs. He folded the papers, put them into the pocket beneath his crest, and made a mental note to send Pax a message that would begin with a courteous insult and end with a compliment Pax would pretend he was not hungry for.

“Lord Varro,” said his quartermaster, appearing the way good quartermasters did, like a necessary thought. “There’s ash dust on the south parapet. Not blow-in. More like shed.”

Caelan’s mouth made the shape his officers called the hinge, which meant a door in him swung, careful and clean. “Show me,” he said, and walked with her along the edge of the field where the stone wall rose chest-high and held back the long drop to the river flats. The ash dust wasn’t much, a pinch here and there, a smudge like extinguished charcoal where it didn’t belong. It made a small shape if you wanted to see a shape. He wanted to. It looked like fingertips. It looked like someone had held their hands above the parapet and shaken them clean.

“The Sovereign’s flies?” the quartermaster said. “Or some boy with a pack and a grudge.”

“Let us pretend to be optimistic before we get to be correct,” he said, and sent for a warder who could read ash the way Roe read sound curves. His Lancers beat their boots five more times and then stopped together. The field hung in the pause as if the world would applaud them and then remembered it wasn’t a theater, it was a training ground for a war you had to be inventive enough to survive without becoming the reason it had to be fought again in twenty years.

Caelan dismissed them with a hand and stood a moment longer with the south light on his face. The song was still faint in him. He could find it if he wanted, the way a scar can be found with a fingertip in the dark. He let it go. He would call for it later when he needed men to march across a bridge toward things that were not supposed to exist and did. He had, however, other logistics to wage before noon, including a Council session that would require the strategic placement of patience like caltrops on a road.

In an apartment in the Old Weavers, where the stairwell smelled like everyone’s lunch and someone’s laundry and you lived your way into other people’s business whether you wanted to or not, Mara Ives woke to the sound of her mother drying the bottoms of bowls with a dishcloth as if bowls scratching the table were a form of original sin. The cat was on her stomach, a weight that suggested loyalty and a refusal to move until bribed. She had slept in the blue-threaded light that belonged to people who had done something too big the day before. Her mouth tasted like the inside of a battery mixed with onion soup and an apology.

She did not open her eyes immediately. She kept them closed and called the ring slowly into her awareness the way you call a nervous creature out from under a table. It came when it wanted to. It sat, dumb as metal. She exhaled and couldn’t decide if that made her glad or frightened. She did not want to be someone who felt abandoned when magic took a nap.

Edda knocked on her door and did not wait for agreement because sometimes the trick of mothering was not asking, it was knowing. “There is tea and there is a man on the screen saying you are the death of culture, so things are moving along at a normal rate,” Edda said, and kept her voice as ordinary as broccoli, because panic would only make this worse.

Mara opened her eyes to the slow calculus of morning. She sat up and slid the ring off where she had slept with it palmed in case it decided to go wandering. She put it on the windowsill and it made a small noise that may have been glass making space for metal. Her body felt heavier than she was used to being. There was a bruise blooming on her left forearm she did not remember earning, and it looked like a fingerprint left by a thing too cold to be a person.

In the small kitchen, the morning news had been bullied into public service. The woman reading it wore a mouth line like she had once operated a ferry in a storm. The words under her were a collection of the city’s favorite arguments: pop or sacred, Charter or stunt, harm or help, maiden or not your business. There was a small box with a priest in it, and another small box with a historian who had published a book about the Quietites and was good at behaving like he was born in the wrong century and that was the city’s fault. There were calls queued from men with chain-store shirts and women from the laundry cooperatives who had noticed their machines sing back to them a note lower this morning.

Edda poured her tea with the attention of a surgeon. “Pax sent a message at six like he was afraid he would get in trouble if he didn’t tell me where my daughter was. A car will pick you up at ten. He says wear what makes you feel least compromised. He did not explain how you are meant to know what that is.”

Mara leaned against the counter with her cup and felt like she had smuggled something back from a country she had been told did not exist. “You should have been at the studio,” she said, immediate guilt rising like a habit. “I should have asked them to—”

“You should have sung the song and come home. Which you did,” Edda said, and tapped the ring with an index finger the way you touch the fur of an animal you suspect might be venomous and also knows it’s very pretty. “I watched you on the replay while you were asleep. The end made me want to swear too loudly for the cat.”

“I didn’t have an end,” Mara said. “It just came and then there wasn’t anything else after it, so stopping felt like the only honest thing. I suppose that is art. Or a lapse.”

Edda folded the dishcloth like folding could bring peace to the world. “You are going to tell men with medals that their medals are on the wrong jackets, eventually. That is not art; that is a personality trait. Eat something so you don’t faint and let them say it was nerves. You will faint when the doctor tells you bad news at sixty-eight and you don’t want me to worry. You will not faint on television.”

Mara chewed the bread like a person making a pact. The cat looked up and then put his head back down like fragile men in fragile times everywhere. Her phone vibrated and she picked it up because the habit was stronger than her resolve. Messages jammed themselves into a stream, a messy river of hearts and knives and the sort of anonymous earnestness that smelled weirdly like loneliness. There were four from Kestrel, whose eyeliner could declare a small war, each a different form of profanity that meant I saw you, which was a love letter of its own.

She sent a reply that was a heart and a thundercloud and a sentence Kestrel would not forgive her for softening. She set the phone back down because it felt like a small animal that might bite her, and she did not have time to be bitten by small animals. She went to the window and looked at the river and thought of how she was supposed to go from here to a building with doors that wanted to close on women like her and call it an accident.

On the other side of the city, in a place that had learned to be quiet because being loud was disallowed and punished, Silas Brune held a piece of old mortar and drew a circle on the floor with it. The circle wasn’t very good. It had a place that went indented like a soft body under a thumb. He tried again, and the guard on the end of the tier did not tell him to stop because the guard was reading something that pretended to be a magazine and was actually a pamphlet about going south in the spring and growing peppers. Silas had managed to beg another sheet of paper out of the librarian with the soft shoulders and the less soft smile. He had bribed her with a sentence that made her laugh against her will. He wasn’t proud of using his language like that, but he used his hands and his head for worse things; he was economical with his sins when he could be.

The prison had hummed all night, the way old buildings hum when the pipes have a secret. He had got up twice because the bed had tried to break him into the parts he had tried to avoid thinking about. He had stood at the bars and put his face into the cold and thought of the woman’s voice threaded through the stone like the river got lost in walls. He had not expected music to be a kindness; he was suspicious of kindness under any circumstances. It had not asked him to feel better. It had not forgiven him anything. It had put its arm around his shoulders for three breaths and then gone on to do other work. He respected that sort of love.

The circle was for a test he had read about in a book someone had smuggled in when he had been a younger man who thought tricks would save him. The book had been confiscated and then thrown back at him because the guard who had opened it had thought the sentences were outside of their job description. Silas closed his eyes and tried to hear one note from the song again. He tried to find the thin thread that had wrapped around his tongue like a wire. He held the pen he had hidden under his mattress and put the tip to the floor and wrote a letter to a woman who did not know his name except in the way a city knows the names of its thieves and its singers.

He wrote: I do not think you are a miracle. I think you are an accident with exactly the right edges. I think you arrived the way knives arrive in corridors, which is to say someone left a door open and a life went from one room to another.

He stopped and looked at the sentence and hated himself for the way it assumed he had the right to name her. He wanted to scratch it out and cannot because stone holds what you write on it like a promise. He made the second circle around the first and told himself it was geometry, not superstition. The wall beyond his cell had a seam in it now he could feel with the heel of his hand if he pressed in the right place, a hairline that caught skin like a whisper. He did not intend to dig. He was past intending. He was not past listening.

Shortly before ten, the car came for Mara as they had said it would. It had windows that made people look like they were made of a more expensive glass than people generally are. Pax’s driver had the face of a man who had left a war halfway down a hill and would cheerfully drive a car through a wall for the right reasons. Pax was not in the car, which was a relief and a disappointment both. There was a folder on the seat next to her, and the folder contained papers with Pax’s handwriting on them, which looked like a person doing calligraphy while the building burned. There were three talking points in case she needed them. There were eight lines telling her to not read the talking points if she could stand it.

Caelan took the steps up to the Council Tower with a grace that did not belong to a man who had been dead and had been told to walk anyway. The Tower still had the smell of the old Church in it. It did not always acknowledge the difference between men who wore collars because they had saved a city and men who wore collars because they had decided God needed an assistant. He passed under the carved names of those who had drafted the Charter, and he touched two of them out of habit. The third he did not touch because the man had been a genius about sound and a cruel husband, and Caelan tried not to make that sort of compromise before noon.

The Council chamber had a table that pretended to be a circle and was actually a horseshoe, which was the city in furniture. There were place cards with names and the preference a man had for water with or without lemon. There were microphones like flowers. The Lord Governor sat and did not stand to greet anyone, because it was one of his small pleasures; Caelan did not penalize a man for taking small pleasures, but he kept a ledger of them just in case. Pax was there with a suit jacket his mother would have called impertinent. He had no tie and a pocket square so dark it was almost a laugh about blood.

“I would like to begin with a word we do not often use in this room,” Pax said before anyone else could get their throat around a phrase like public safety. “Thank you.”

The Lord Governor did not roll his eyes because he had improved his public face in the last year and a half. He made the more subtle move of smoothing his moustache. “We will dispense with courtesy and go to obligation,” he said, and the clerk’s pencil made a noise like a match striking as if it had independent feelings. “The Charter of Sound requires consent given in writing and before witnesses before any broadcast intended to awaken the Gates. The singer last night was a young woman with no previous appearance in this chamber and no posted contract on file. You circumvented—”

“I spoke to her,” Pax said, with his hand flat on the table like he could nail his argument down with it. “I explained the Charter and its protections. She agreed. We recorded her agreement; Roe has the minutes and the time stamp. The Charter is not offended by pop. It is offended by coercion.”

“The city is offended by midnight stunts,” said a man Caelan didn’t particularly care for, whose family owned the rights to most of the city’s night markets and therefore believed himself both a merchant and a poet. “The city is offended by surprises that make guards call in and wives call out and people stop what they are doing to dance on the kerb. We could have had a panic.”

“We did not,” Caelan said, and allowed his voice to be a little more metal than usual. He preferred to hold tone like a baton rather than swing it, but sometimes it was useful to let the sound show its teeth. “We had an adjustment. The men and women under my charge yesterday sang at their posts while they did their jobs. Their jobs went well. The ash along the south parapet tells me we made someone across the river think, which is one of my favorite things to make an enemy do.”

“There was ash on the parapet?” said the Lord Governor, doing a small acting like he had not known. He had known. “That should have been sent to the Division.”

“The Division will have their pinch,” Caelan said, and did not smile. “This is not a meeting about ash. This is a meeting about control. I am here to tell you that sometimes the control you think you hold is the thing that will strangle you. The Charter is alive. It has slept. Last night someone shook it awake. It will snarl if you try to put it in a glass case and admire your reflections upon it.”

Pax made a small grateful nonsense noise he probably believed no one heard. Caelan heard everything. He did not turn his head to look at the door when it opened because men who believe themselves to own rooms look at doors. They did not. He could smell her in the hallway before she came in, a sweat that was very clean and very honest, a note of onion and something like metal after rain. The clerk announced her the way clerks do when the room is full and the person in the doorway is the occasion.

Mara walked in and her boots made a sound that was not embarrassed. She had put her hair up and then let one piece fall on purpose because she had practiced and then given up and that was the piece that refused her. Her jacket was less cute than last night and more deliberate. She had a small notebook in her hand like a talisman and a look on her face that said she had slept and had not slept, which was the look of every person who had done something their city asked for and then could not decide whether to present a bill.

“They would like to ask me whether I consent to having consented,” she whispered to Pax when she stood beside him, and he made a small pained parent laugh he would deny until his dying day.

“We would like to ask you if you understand the role you have thrust yourself into,” the Lord Governor said, and then realized thrust had been a poor choice because the older women on the Council all made the same small face at once. He coughed the kind of cough that means a man has been interrupted by his own vocabulary. “Miss Ives. Thank you for attending. You are very young.”

“I am twenty,” she said, and her voice did not apologize for being twenty. “You are using words like maiden in my letters. Do you know what it is like to have a city discuss your sexual status before breakfast. I don’t recommend it. I recommend you discuss whether last night helped the Gates breathe and whether I am allowed to decide what to do with my throat.”

There was a long, delicate silence in which several men moved pens and shuffled papers as if papers might save them from words. Caelan had to restrain an unprofessional noise. He looked down the table and saw two women he had fought beside in the last sick summer hide smiles in their water glasses. The Lord Governor folded his hands as if he could make a church between them.

“We do not intend to strip you,” he began, and then stopped because he was not that clumsy a man, and yet the word had been standing there waiting and he had walked right into it. “We do not intend to deprive you of any Charter right. The Charter is the reason the Lancers are yours and not enemies. The Charter restrains us all. The Charter also provides for responsibility. If you wield the Charter ring without the backing of the Choir, you open us to—”

“Who is the Choir now?” Mara said, and there was no quite successful way for him to say a word like Interim because it would make the room smell of the ruined church on Grave Lane. He did not answer. She put her notebook down so she wouldn’t squeeze it. “The Choir are women who didn’t want to be told when to sing or what to wear to sing. They left. We wrote new songs in kitchens. The city kept itself from becoming the wrong sort of quiet. I am here as a woman who wants very badly to be small and who can’t be, not now, because someone sent me a ring. My consent is a moving thing. I gave it last night. I am not giving it to you for forever. If I write another song using the Charter, it will be because I have to, not because this room told me it was what nice girls do.”

Pax exhaled in a way that was performed for him alone. Caelan took the tenor of the room again and found it had shifted a half step toward honesty and discomfort, which was where things could be done. The Lord Governor adjusted his lemon water and nodded a nod that was both a concession and an investment in later arguments. He glanced down the line at one of his advisors, a thin man whose forefinger had ink under the nail, and the man made a note that would become a policy by afternoon.

They asked her then the questions they were allowed to ask because they had memorized the Charter’s limits. Did she understand the Gate’s temper, the city’s tendency to vibrate at certain frequencies until people could not hear themselves think and then did dangerous things? Did she have anyone advising her besides Pax, and could Roe be compelled to share the tapes, and did the ring injure her, and had she seen anything while she sang that she interpreted as an omen? She said yes where yes was true and no where no was not untrue. She said Roe was a witch who would eat anyone who tried to compel her and that the tapes were safer with Roe than with any of the men in this room. She said the ring did not injure and also it did, and both were correct. She said she had seen a corridor where a bad choice had been made and that she had no plan to sing in corridors for fun.

They released her when they realized she was the sort of person whose yeses and nos were not transactions in the way their yeses and nos were. Pax walked her out and then put his back to the closed door and breathed like a man who had come down five flights of stairs too fast. He shook his hands out as if to remove electricity and failed because electricity liked him. He did not hug her because she would have bitten him on instinct.

“You said what you had to say and you did not give them the parts they wanted,” he said, which was a review and a benediction. “We have an appearance at noon to explain pop to the sort of person who thinks drums are a conspiracy. Then I will try to stop three newspapers from printing the word virgin in your headline. I will fail at two and win at one because that is the ratio of sin to grace we get in this city.”

Mara stood in the corridor and looked at the place where the stone met the wood and thought she could feel a hum that did not belong to buildings and was not hers. It ran along the baseboard like a thin vein. She stepped lightly and it stepped with her for a moment and then hid. “I would like to eat a pastry,” she said. “I would like the pastry to be so sugary it offends someone. I would like to do that before anyone asks me to carry a sword, metaphorical or otherwise.”

“Done,” Pax said, and the relief in his face at a practical request made her want to kick him and pat him on the shoulder at once. “There is a place with a woman who pretends to hate me and will give you the last perfect thing on the tray if I give her a look that says I remember the war and let her call me names.”

They went out through the northern doors because the western ones were guarded by people with lenses and Pax had a sense of humor but it did not extend to handing his singer to the people who made their wages out of getting you to say the thing that started the fire. The northern steps were an acceptable small descent into being looked at. A woman with a baby in a sling called, “You did good,” and then clapped a hand over her mouth as if she had sworn. A man with paint under his nails and the smell of fixative said, “That chord was illegal,” with the expression of a person who has been waiting his entire life for someone to give him permission to make an error on purpose. A boy with braces yelled her name wrong and looked as if the metal were burning him.

Caelan watched them go from the shade of a column and did not follow. His job this hour was to go to the south parapet and read ash and then to take a dozen Lancers into the tunnels because a scout had heard things he did not like and he was not a man who left dislike alone to behave itself. He sent a single message to Pax that was a warning disguised as a joke: The Division’s eyes have turned foxward. Keep your birds inside. Pax replied with a lightning bolt and a knife and the word soup, because he believed in code as a way to comfort himself.

Marrowgate Prison woke to breakfast like it always did: the sound of trays and the steam that made men think of other kitchens and the sudden loudness of men existing in a space together without the buffers they had in the world. Silas did not get up immediately. He watched the seam in the wall across from him expand a fraction and then stop as if it had changed its mind. He sat up slowly because rushing made the day worse. He put his feet on the floor like they were new and might not trust him yet.

The guard with the pepper pamphlet came down the tier with his belt jangling like a small bell. He slid the tray into Silas’s cell and did not make a joke about porridge because that had been done for three hundred years too many. “You get a visitor this afternoon,” he said, as if he were saying a word like shampoo. “Don’t stab him.”

Silas looked up at him and let the silence sit one count longer than comfortable and then asked, “Who?”

The guard shrugged and failed to make it a movement that did not mean something. “Some woman in a coat with a patch that says she’s a friend of music. Says she’s doing a survey of men who wrote songs when they were young and then made mistakes. I said we didn’t have any of those. She said, ‘Then I will take a man who used to write letters and forgot how.’ She gave me an apple and it didn’t look poisoned. You should shave. You look like you sawed your face with a spoon.”

Silas did not laugh at the spoon because he had once seen a man open another man with a spoon, and you can only laugh at some things in some rooms and live. He waited until the guard had gone and then he put his hands against the seam again and the seam did not respond because it was morning and the song was not throbbing through the stone the way it had last night. He told himself not to imagine that a woman with a coat was going to bring him a rope made of sound. He told himself he would be polite and not tell her the alternative life he was writing had her room in it. He told himself and did not believe himself because the morning had arrived and with it the small unnatural hope that comes when magic has crossed a city you lived in long enough to think you had mapped.

The pastry shop was the sort of place you bring secrets and pretend they are crumbs. It had windows with hand lettering and a woman behind the counter with a mouth that could stop a clock. Pax went in like a man entering confession. The woman said his name with the precise weight that suggests you once took a bullet together and also that she believes he owes her five favors. She looked at Mara and made the small noise mothers make when a child is in the room who has done a thing for the house and is now standing there with their hair not quite combed.

“I have nothing left but the things no one else can carry,” the woman said, and lifted a tray where three squares rested with sugar on them like the first snow on a roof. “Also a doughnut that is having an identity crisis.”

Mara chose a square and regretted not being able to choose all of them the way a person regrets not being able to live all their lives. She put the first bite in her mouth and nearly cried because it tasted like butter and sugar and the absence of violence. Pax ate the identity crisis and looked like a man who deserved his fate. The shop was full of people being ordinary at high volume. A girl at the corner table had taken a guitar out and was playing the wrong chords with such determination you had to approve. A boy at the window was drawing a map of the city onto his sleeve with a pen because sometimes you had to carry the place you belonged on your body like a threat.

“I got a letter,” the woman said to Pax, and put her hands on the counter to force him to be serious. “It says they will audit me. It says I had twenty-two rolls go missing in a week and the City thinks that means I am paying for certain things with bread. I am paying for nothing with bread except my rent and a boy who insists hot chocolate is a human right.”

Pax made a face at the word audit the way men made faces in the old days when a priest said confession and meant theater. “You give the Lancers a tray twice a week when something goes wrong at their training. I pull you out of the audit by afternoon. You plan in case I cannot.”

“I have never been without a plan,” she said, and glanced at Mara the way you glance when you are making sure someone eats enough to do what you know they have to do. “Don’t let them tell you you are a thing they own. A room full of men is a room full of wishful thinking. You do the part you can live with. You give the rest to whoever pretends to like suffering and suits.”

Outside, the street had decided that looking was not impolite if you did it with admiration instead of intrusiveness, which would have been flattering if admiration did not have a way of turning to hunger without warning. Kestrel found her outside the pastry shop the way bird dogs find things they have flushed, with her eyeliner like two precise wounds and her grin like a charm twice used and still potent. She grabbed Mara’s wrist and then remembered she was a person and not her scarf and let go.

“You did it,” Kestrel said, and then shook her head hard enough to upset her balance. “No. You did a thing no one else can be caught doing. That’s ruder, which I respect more. I heard men trying to decide if they could still like ballads. I told them their grandmothers listened to laments while they repaired roof tiles and they made babies to the sound of rain, so yes.”

Mara breathed in Kestrel’s smell of cigarettes she didn’t smoke and perfume she pretended she couldn’t afford. “The city is being very loud,” she said, and Kestrel bumped her shoulder the way women bump each other when pushing a car out of mud.

“They are going to eat you and then worship you and then want your skin as wallpaper. That’s the ritual. You are going to have to learn to want things loudly so there’s no room for their wants. I brought you this,” Kestrel said, and shoved a pair of sunglasses at her that looked like they belonged to someone who lived on a balcony. “They will not help. They will make you feel like they help, which sometimes is the only help anyone can give.”

They were laughing, the kind of laughing that has claws and helps anyway, when a man stepped away from the shadow of a doorway and smiled with the flexible mouth of a person trained to convince you of nice things and bad things at once. He wore a coat that belonged to the office called Annotations, a coat that said, We like documents and order and we would like to know the details of the life you are living so we can make a better list. He held a white envelope the way you hold bread. He was careful with his eyes; he did not look directly at the ring.

“Miss Ives,” he said, and somehow the way he said it made Pax appear between Mara and the space the man was standing like a very elegant storm. “Apologies for the abruptness. My name’s Aron Tull, from Annotations. We’re all very proud. We would like to make certain your documents smile in the correct places. Small thing. A signature on a form that says—officially, you know—that the ring is presently in your custody and that you understanding its chain of provenance is under investigation.”

Pax had been built for moments when men came with paper and tried to turn the world into a series of squares they could move around without looking up. He took the envelope like a man accepts a compliment, with half a smile and three teeth. “My documents will giggle when they see yours,” he said. “We will bring them to your office after we have taught them manners. Good morning.”

The man moved as if to insist and then had the rare survival instinct that told him a bad morning could become a very bad morning if he moved his hand in a particular way. He left his card. He walked away the way men walk when they think you are going to watch them. Pax put the envelope into his coat because he never threw anything away until he had read it three times with and without the lights on. He did not tell Mara not to worry because that is a useless sentence.

“Men in coats,” said Kestrel, because some advice you carry with you because your mother was right the first time and you don’t need to improve it. “Edda will cut him to ribbons with a bread knife.”

There was a tremor underfoot that made all three of them adjust their balance. It was not a subway or a cart. It was not the wind. It was the Gates giving a breath and then holding it. People on the street went quiet the way city people do when the thing that keeps their corners in place reminds them that it can move. Mara felt the ring against her bone though she wasn’t touching it, which was alarming and then embarrassing because it meant she had thought she could leave it on the windowsill and be its boss.

Caelan and a dozen Lancers were already underground by then, not beneath the Gates themselves but beneath the parts of the city the Gates had loved in other lives. The tunnels smelled like drowned metal and stories. Their lights made the sort of small sound lights make when they touch old magic and pretend it is dust. Jaro, a soldier with a laugh that had survived too many things, was to his right, and Ran, who had once taken a vow that she didn’t realize tied her to nine years of being angry and then broke it in a courtyard with rain, was to his left.

They moved along the curve of a maintenance passage until it opened onto a chamber that had been a place for sorting before the Ash Wars. The Chamber of Numbers had seen the movement of as many people as any cathedral. Caelan told them to hold, because holding could save lives as often as it cost them. He closed his eyes with a soldier’s arrogance and he looked with the kind of looking that had nothing to do with sight. The song had left a residue here. It had dusted the old markings into relief the way a child rubs charcoal over paper to show a coin’s face.

There was ash, but it wasn’t scattered. It was arranged in a shape that had no reason to be alive and was. It looked like a door when you squinted. It looked like a hand when you didn’t. It looked like someone had tried to teach the ash to speak and had gotten as far as a letter O and then had to run. Caelan stepped closer and the ash formed itself in the smallest shiver that could be written off as your own heart. He put his hand out and stopped before his palm touched empty air. He left it there like a man considering a handshake.

“Do we touch it,” Jaro said, and stood like a man who has decided not to die today if he can help it.

“We ask it a question first,” Caelan said. He pitched his voice to the tone you use for dogs you trust and children you love and old gods you suspect might have finally improved their tempers. “Who sent you.”

The ash moved with the delicacy of falling hair. The O became a shape the warders would recognize as a sign from before. It wasn’t a word, not in their alphabet. It was a pressure that made you think of a body leaning against a door. Ran swore and then apologized to a deity she did not believe in because swearing is sometimes a social reflex.

“Someone is pushing,” Caelan said. “It is not the Sovereign. He does not knock. He makes holes and calls them entrances.”

“Then who,” Ran said, and got no answer because the city was busy and had not scheduled a moment for that answer to arrive. The ash dropped as if a hand had withdrawn. The chamber returned to being a place where numbers had been sorted. Caelan inhaled and tasted sugar in the air where there should have been rust. He filed that away next to the word Kestrel in his mind because he needed the women in eyeliner to live and keep their secrets and there was only so much space for sugar underground.

Mara stood on the steps of a building that would like to have been in a different argument and answered three questions before she was asked. She said the ring did not make her sane or insane. She said she liked drums and ballads and songs that made a street stop spinning. She said she would finish a pastry before she finished a thought if she could manage it. Then she did the thing that was going to make Pax say Please don’t hurt me later. She took the ring out and put it on her finger in front of the cameras and nothing happened for a heartbeat and then, because the world could not help itself, something did.

The lights on the street flickered in time to the memory of the song and then steadied. The Gates two bridges away inhaled and exhaled like men in a line preparing to step into their night. Edda right then at her kitchen table slapped a hand down over the headlines that tried to enter her house like rude relatives and said, “Stop it,” and then laughed at herself because she had just told the city to mind its manners.

In Marrowgate, Silas’s visitor came in smelling like lavender and dust and the inside of new books. She wore a coat with a patch that did say Friend of Music, which was a polite lie. Silas stood because he believed in theater when there was very little else to believe in. She had a file in her hands and a look in her eyes like she enjoyed finding holes and putting names into them. She set the file down and looked at his circles on the floor and at his face and then at the seam in the wall and he saw the moment she decided to pretend she had not seen anything. He admired that sort of professionalism. It was a hell of a thing to pretend to miss something and then make sure your job remembered you had.

“You wrote songs once,” she said, and the vowels admitted she had parents who had wanted her to speak like a teacher and a child who had taught her how not to. “Letters after that. We have a program. We take men who are good with sentences and teach them how to put them into places where the city can’t do much damage. Grant writing. Public notices. A pamphlet about teaching kettles to purr.”

Silas looked at her hands and noticed they were too clean for a person who handled files. He wondered if her desk had been invented for her so she could put out her hands to make people think she came from paper. “I killed a boy in a corridor,” he said, and he did not soften it because softening things is lying and this was not a room that wanted lies; it was a room that wanted unpleasantries said with a flat tone so they could be filed.

She did not flinch the way men flinch. She made a small noise in her throat like a woman who had once cut her hand on a jar and did not tell anyone and got on with the soup. “Yes,” she said. “The boy was part of a list I keep. The list is in my head because paper is too kind. You do not get out of jail because you write a pamphlet. Don’t ask. It makes the conversation long and then makes me late to the next conversation. You could write in here. You could make lines other people will read and keep. You could stop writing to a woman you think you can save if you call her in the right tense.”

Silas put his hands on the table and thought if he pressed hard enough his palms would grow roots and he would be a tree with a man’s head and birds would nest in his hair. “I am not writing to save anyone,” he said. “I am writing so there is a version of me somewhere that does not deserve what he has and does not try to make that mean anything.”

She nodded. She slid a stapled packet across the table, which was the shape of this conversation. He could either staple himself to something or not. There was a line on the second page where he could let words become wages in a place that had none. She reached into her bag and put an apple on the table because apparently this week men in rooms with no fruit got apples. He wanted to make a joke about it but no joke was as funny as living. She said her name was Lale. She did not tell him where she bought the coat patch. He signed, because there are forms of hope that do not embarrass you and this was one.

When the second noon had got itself done, and the city had decided it still existed, Mara sat in the back of another car and stared at her hands and tried to decide if they were hers. Pax had a voice left and used it to tell someone that if they wanted to film her mother’s building they should wear nicer shoes. He had a voice left because Roe had given him a throat lozenge that made you feel like a library was opening in your chest. Caelan had sent a message that said simply, south tunnels. Later. Because he had set aside a sliver of a day to tell her something about swords and the parts of a city that refused to be drawn on a map, and because he could smell the other thing coming and wanted not to waste time when time made faces.

There was a gift waiting when she got upstairs that made Edda say three syllables of an old prayer, which is two syllables and a hand. It was a bouquet of paper flowers, folded with such care it almost made you like their maker, except that when Mara touched the edge of a petal it turned to ash. There was a small card with handwriting too polite. It said: Return the ring to sleep. It said: We will be gentle first.

Edda took the flowers to the sink and ran water over them as if water could outvote ritual, and they did not turn to ash under the tap. They stayed paper and ugly. Mara put her hand on the counter and tried to decide if she was a person who would be frightened now or later. The ring lay where she had left it on the sill and did not hum. Pax’s messages burned holes in her pocket. Caelan’s promise sat like a stone at the bottom of a river. The city was being very honest about wanting to rearrange her.

That night, when men in coats had drunk their tea and gone home to houses in neighborhoods that didn’t get ash on the parapets, when the Lancers had eaten something like food and laughed at jokes they would not remember next week, when Kestrel came by and pretended she needed to borrow salt and left with three jars of jam and a glare, Mara took the ring into the bathroom like it was a confidante. She sat on the closed lid of the toilet and looked at her face and did not decide whether she liked it. She put the ring on and said a number out loud she had not said in public in fifteen years. The ring made a sound like a kettle remembering itself.

The melody that arrived was not the one she had made. It was narrower. It was the sort of tune an alley might sing to announce that it was safe to leave a back door unlatched for someone who needed to come in and sit on the floor for a minute. She hummed into it and let words catch. She did not think about audiences. She did not think about Ash. She thought about men in rooms who wrote their other lives on stone and women who hit rings with their knuckles and made them behave. She thought about drums and onion soup and the way sugar can taste underground if you are careful.

Down in the south tunnels, Caelan put his hand to the place where the ash had been and felt nothing but cool stone and the memory of a pressure like a stranger’s forehead against yours. Jaro said something obscene about luck and Ran reminded him luck is a person and she charges rent. They turned to go and three of them turned back because they thought they heard a man laughing. It wasn’t a nice laugh. It was the kind of laugh that shakes out of a person like a cough. The sound didn’t come from the door shape or the O or any of the places a sensible man would look. It came from a seam in the wall that would not be a seam unless you were the sort of person who had read too many names and asked for more.

Caelan touched the seam without touching it. He thought of a corridor and a boy and a knife and a long thin wire of a song pulled taut through someone else’s throat. He did not know that across the city a man in a cell had just signed his name to a program that would teach him to name objects until naming them made him less of one. He did not know that a woman upstairs in a bathroom on a street with old trees had just found a tune you could carry home in your pocket without anyone noticing.

He did know the difference between knocking and not. He knew that the Ash Sovereign did not ask for permission. He knew someone else might. He kept his hand steady over the seam and said the sort of sentence you say to a room when you would like it to believe you are not afraid and would like to believe that too. He said, “Not tonight.”

The seam held. The room did not open. The ash did not return. The city, tired of pretending, rolled itself onto the other shoulder and slept the kind of sleep that admits it has a problem. In apartments like explosives and closets like boats, people relistened because relistening is a form of prayer. In a prison like a throat, a man fell asleep with ink on his fingers. In a kitchen like a safe place, a mother put a bowl over a paper flower and decided it wasn’t allowed to harm her house because she said so. In a tower like a mistake, a governor wrote a sentence in a speech that included the word maiden, and then crossed it out, and wrote it again, and crossed it out again, and settled for citizen because he had to live with the women who would hear him.

At the window in the blue-threaded light of three in the morning, Mara pressed her palm flat to the pane. The ring was warm. The river moved as if someone had put a chord under it. She did not promise herself away. She did not promise herself to herself, either; the world had taught her that was a dangerous sort of vow. She breathed and counted to seven and then lost the numbers because a rhythm had found her that was not counting and was not silence and was not the city taking what it wanted. It was the small sound you make when you decide to be brave again tomorrow. It was not an anthem. It did not have a beat you could dance to, unless your dance was the sort where you lean on a counter and laugh too loud so you will know you are alive.

Morning took a long time deciding to arrive in the Old Weavers and, when it did, it came through the kitchen window like someone late to a party bringing bread to apologize. Edda had already done the practical warfare of wiping down the table twice, not because it was dirty but because doing so put the world temporarily into her jurisdiction. The paper flower sat under a mixing bowl, which made the cat very religious about the bowl, circling it and saying quiet cat things to it as if prayer would keep unfortunate paper from learning new tricks. Mara poured tea and did not put the ring on until she had watched the steam for three long breaths and decided she had the edges for it. The weight on her finger altered the taste of the tea; she could taste a faint metal that was not cup and not spoon, an optimism that made her want to swear and knock on wood simultaneously.

Kestrel arrived with a speed that made you suspect she had been downstairs on the second-floor landing timing the moments between footsteps. She threw herself into a chair like it was about to be stolen and put a folded piece of onion-skin paper on the table with reverence and profanity co-existing in the gesture. The paper was thinner than a whisper and twice as sure of itself. Inside it, a hand had written with a nib that had a lot of opinions: We have hot water and we do not waste it on men. Bring your throat. Old Baths, noon. It smelled faintly of rosemary, the way old sweat can if it has been mixed with years of soap and women’s conversations about things no council ever included on their agendas.

Edda dried her hands and looked at the paper like it came from a school friend she had laughed with three governments ago. She touched the edge and then touched Mara’s wrist. “You should go,” she said, and the should had a weight to it like a bowl you set down firmly so that it doesn’t try to participate in the argument. “If you are going to carry a ring with this much bad manners, you should at least speak with the women who taught the last one to mind its shoes indoors.”

Mara wanted to say she had a meeting with Pax and another meeting with a man whose job title was a form of apology, but the paper’s rosemary smell reached into her and arranged her objections into less useful shapes. She drank the tea. She ate the end of a heel of bread she did not want. She put her hand flat over the bowl with the paper flower and felt nothing but porcelain and inherited stubbornness, which relieved her more than she expected it to. “Noon,” she said, and saw the way both women in the room half exhaled like a bellows releasing.

The Old Baths had been retired three times—by war, by fashion, by men who liked to put taxes on things women enjoyed—and survived each retirement by pretending to be a ruin until the new rules forgot they existed. The street outside them did not remember when carriages had clattered and men had tipped hats; it remembered quilts hung on lines and steam like early fog and small, savage arguments over which soap made the best lather for hair that behaved like weather. The door had a polite sign that said Closed for Private Restoration, which was the city’s way of saying You do not have enough knowledge to come in right now. Kestrel knocked the knock women knock in funny corners to tell other women they are not here to rearrange anybody. The lock took a moment to remember who it had been forged for and then yielded with a sound like a small regret.

Inside, the air was gratitude and humidity. The tiled room had not been allowed to be pretty; it had insisted on it instead. On the far wall, under a fresco of women with hair like rivers who had lasted out three faiths and never been repainted, sat six women and a kettle. They were not old or young. They were all the ages that mattered. Three of them were now-famous cowards who had refused to stand up and sing when asked by a dead church with a live appetite and the city had survived anyway. Two wore smocks. One wore a coat with pockets that were either full of instruments or full of small knives. None of them stood. None of them smiled in the preliminary way.

“You,” said the one in the coat, who had salt on her cuffs and steam in her voice. “You argued with the water last night until it remembered it needed to boil. Sit. Shoes off. Rings off. We do not drop things in the hot that we haven’t named.”

Mara took off her boots and set them aside with the care you use for friends. She slipped the ring and put it on her palm. It hummed exactly once like a short laugh, and then made a display of being obedient. She sat on the tile, which cooled her at once and made her feel like a child at kitchen level. Kestrel sat cross-legged beside her, and the eyeliner made her look like a very precise heretic. The kettle poured into small cups as if pouring were a sacrament and not a mechanics of gravity.

“We are not the Choir,” said a woman with a line of scars that disappeared under the neck of her shirt and reappeared near her wrist like a small river that got lost and then found itself again. “We were the whisper behind the Choir, the aunties, the thieves, the ones who wrote the lists when the men thought lists were theirs. The Choir scattered rather than be told when to inhale. We did not scatter. We went to make soap and raise boys and teach girls that singing is not performance, it is barricade. The card you got was rude. We do apologies after. I am Soria.”

Mara balanced the cup in both hands and dared to smell it. It was not rosemary. It was lavender and something like iron. It was the smell of the basin in her grandmother’s yard, the one she remembered without ever having seen. “I am Mara,” she said, and felt foolish at introducing herself to women who had already decided what she was to them. “I have something that doesn’t belong to me and I used it and it worked and now the city is making noises like furniture being dragged upstairs at an hour when furniture should not be dragged anywhere. I don’t want to be owned by it. Or by the city. Or by anyone with a patch. I also don’t want to let the Gates go back to sleep. How ridiculous to want anything at all.”

Kestrel put a shoulder lightly against Mara’s as if to stop her from listing too hard. Soria made a how-old-are-you face that had nothing to do with numbers and everything to do with what you had given up to keep your throat for yourself. “It does not belong to anyone,” she said. “The ring belongs to the city we want, not to the city we have. It is not obedient. It prefers cleverness. You have some. You will need more. They will ask you to give it back to sleep. They will say that sleep is safer. Perhaps for them. You will go on not sleeping well for a while. The only thing you must not do is pretend to be quiet when you are not built for it. That will ruin you. We prefer our girls unruined, or at least ruined in interesting ways that annoy the correct men.”

A laugh went around the tile like quick water. Mara tried out the smile that was showing up on the faces of women who were not her and found that it fit her mouth as if it had been there before. “The song last night,” said the one with the pockets of tools or knives, and her voice had a tiny line in it that said she had once been paid to sing to men who could not find sleep any other way. “There was a bleed. Did you feel it.”

Mara thought of sugar underground and men in tunnels tasting sweets that had no business in rust. “Something else rode it,” she said, and the women made the sound women make when they have been waiting to hear someone else say the thing their bodies had already told them. “I was told to keep it dirty and I did and something took the dirt and drew in it. It made an O. It pressed itself against a door and did not knock.”

“The ash faction isn’t interested in asking,” said Soria, which made the tile feel briefly colder. “That is someone else. We thought perhaps one of the Quiets had gotten out of a grave and decided to be polite before being unkind. But the politeness smelled like sugar, which they thought was a sin and which we know to be breakfast. There is a girl under the river who uses sugar to teach ash to be letters. She is either going to save us or make a very beautiful mess. Both, probably.”

Kestrel made a face that announced her two opinions about girls under rivers and both of those opinions involved rescuing and lecturing.
